headline: Attack of the Fanatical Centrists
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Of obsessions, vanity and delusions of superiority.
lead_paragraph: Why is American politics so dysfunctional? Whatever the deeper roots of our distress, the proximate cause is ideological extremism: Powerful factions are committed to false views of the world, regardless of the evidence.

headline: Trump Returns This Weekend to Mar-a-Lago, His Gilded Comfort Zone
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: In his Palm Beach cocoon, President Trump is in his most comfortable mode, friends and allies say: playing the host in front of an adoring crowd.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two months spent scorching the earth in Washington and complaining about being cooped up in the White House, President Trump is planning to return this weekend to the one place where he knows he will receive a hero’s welcome for his troubles: Mar-a-Lago, his gilded club by the sea in Palm Beach.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Says Retiree Benefits Are a Priority
abstract: The association will push for more generous benefits for all retired players in negotiations over the collective bargaining agreement, which expires after the 2020 season.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, DeMaurice Smith, said Thursday that the union would push for more generous benefits for all retired players in the coming negotiations over the collective bargaining agreement, which expires after the 2020 season.

headline: Trump Administration Eases Regulations on Gun Exports, Raising Concerns
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Arms Trade', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The administration’s plan to shift commercial gun export regulations from the State Department to the Commerce Department should boost overseas sales, but Democrats are worried.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American gun manufacturers and their allies have pressed the federal government for years to change the way it regulates small-arms exports in an effort to ease restrictions, boost gun sales abroad and lower costs at home. The Trump administration appears to be on the brink of delivering.

headline: 18 Accidents, 32 Dead. But Crash Site Clues May Have Been Lost in Shutdown.
abstract: Important evidence in at least 18 fatal accidents could have been lost because so many federal investigators were on furlough.
lead_paragraph: Whenever there is a plane or major highway crash, federal investigators descend immediately to the scene to collect evidence. Their goal is to find the accident’s cause so that future tragedies can be prevented.

abstract: The toughest progressive we’ve seen in a long time.
lead_paragraph: The more you learn about Kamala Harris, the more formidable she appears. She is an amazing amalgam of different elements — highly educated elite meritocrat, Oakland street fighter, crusading, rough-elbow prosecutor, canny machine pol and telegenic rhetorical brawler.

headline: Washington’s Cold Hypocrisy on New York’s Public Housing
abstract: A new agreement adds some federal oversight, but no new funding.

headline: Amazon’s Sales Growth Slows, Even as Cloud Business Stays Hot
abstract: The company is compensating for slowing growth in e-commerce by expanding its fast-moving, highly profitable cloud and advertising businesses.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon held off stiffer competition for online shoppers during the holiday season, once again increasing its sales. But the company said on Thursday that growth slowed from its usual breakneck pace — and it came at a cost, with the company spending far more on shipping to win customers.

headline: Venezuela’s Crisis Reveals Disputes Among Power Brokers at Home and Abroad
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Elections', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The legitimacy of Venezuela’s leadership is at the heart of a domestic crisis and a raging international debate. But how the crisis is resolved may hinge on other factors.
lead_paragraph: If it seems impossible that Venezuela’s government could have remained in power nearly two years into the country’s self-imposed economic collapse, consider that Naunihal Singh, a leading expert on power transitions and coups, is just as baffled as everyone else.

headline: Brazil’s Lethal Environmental Negligence
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Levees and Dams', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The mining industry puts lives at risk with shoddy maintenance of dams built to contain mining waste.
lead_paragraph: After the catastrophic rupture of a mine-tailings dam in Brazil last week, leaving behind at least 110 dead, 238 missing and an environmental disaster of epic proportions, the police were quick to arrest five people who had been responsible for inspecting the dam and who most recently proclaimed it “stable.” Certainly they had erred, and courts will decide whether they did so criminally. But rounding up the usual suspects does not begin to address responsibility for a disaster of this scale and a danger many mining communities face around the world.

headline: Catholic Church in Texas Names Nearly 300 Priests Accused of Sex Abuse
abstract: The state’s 15 Catholic dioceses released information about decades of alleged abuse, but advocates for victims said there was more to be done.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Church in Texas on Thursday released the names of almost 300 priests who it said had been credibly accused of child sex abuse over nearly eight decades.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ Season 2, Episode 3: Guess Who’s Back?
abstract: "Point of Light,” this week’s “Star Trek: Discovery, brought back the Federation’s chief antagonists, the Klingons. This is a species that the writers don’t seem to know what they want to do with.
lead_paragraph: Let’s call this a return to form for “Star Trek: Discovery,” in that “Point Of Light” was the first episode this season to remind me of last season. By which I mean it offered crowded, haphazard and choppy storytelling with bold choices that depart from historic Trek norms. (A suggested decapitation? Yikes!)

abstract: Phone records show that Donald Trump Jr. spoke to family friends — the head of Nascar and an investor with ties to Russia — around a 2016 meeting with Russians promising dirt on Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats have long stoked suspicions about whether President Trump knew his son met with Russians offering dirt on Hillary Clinton during the 2016 campaign, pointing to phone calls that Donald Trump Jr. received from a blocked number around the time of the meeting.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump wanted to talk. He initially invited A. G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, to an off-the-record dinner. Mr. Sulzberger countered with a request for an on-the-record interview that included Times reporters. The White House accepted.

keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s campaign spent $23 million in the final quarter of 2018 as he stumped aggressively for Republican candidates. It reported $19 million in cash on hand.
lead_paragraph: As Democratic candidates begin to file their paperwork to run for president in 2020, they already know they will be facing a well-financed opponent. President Trump’s campaign reported $19.2 million in cash on hand Thursday in a filing with the Federal Election Commission.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Well, that was fun. Ori Brian is back, and he offers us a Friday that experienced solvers might find fairly easy, but there are enough speed bumps to slow you down a bit.

headline: Trump Officials Move to Lower Drug Prices by Passing On Rebates to Patients
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discount Selling', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration proposed on Thursday to require health insurance companies and middlemen to give consumers the benefit of discounts they get on prescription drugs, a huge change that could substantially lower some patients’ costs but could also have unintended consequences.

headline: Howard Schultz Draws Protesters in His Hometown, Seattle
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Schultz, the former chief executive of Starbucks, was greeted by about 40 protesters at an event after saying he would consider running for president as an independent.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — As cars and pedestrians passed by during the evening rush on Thursday, Paula Harper-Christensen, a retired teacher, smiled and waved her sign with an upside-down Starbucks mermaid. “Don’t spill our chance,” the text said under the logo. Susan Glicksberg’s protest placard was more blunt: “Do Not Run!”

headline: Book Written by Detainee via WhatsApp Gets a Top Prize

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A stateless Kurdish-Iranian asylum-seeker detained by the Australian government won the country’s highest-paying literary prize on Thursday. But he could not attend the festivities to accept the award.

headline: ICE Force-Feeds Detainees Who Are on Hunger Strike
abstract: As of Wednesday night, 11 detainees in El Paso had refused to eat, Immigration and Customs Enforcement said. Six of those were being force-fed.
lead_paragraph: Immigration officials have been force-feeding a half dozen detainees who began a hunger strike to protest conditions at a processing center in Texas where they are being held, the authorities said Thursday.

abstract: Two historically black neighborhoods lie in the shadow of the Atlanta stadium hosting this year’s Super Bowl, but the riches its creation represents? Just out of reach.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — There is a history of broken promises here, in English Avenue and Vine City, two neighborhoods near Mercedes-Benz Stadium, which will host the Super Bowl on Sunday. Built with more than $700 million in public funds for construction and future maintenance, the approximately $1.5 billion stadium opened in grand fashion in 2017 near these historically black neighborhoods, two of the poorest in the Southeast.

headline: Want Lasting Love? First, Take This Test
abstract: After her marriage unravels, a woman seeks answers in personality testing and the science of compatibility.
lead_paragraph: I asked Claire to take the test after our third date. Things had gone well — hands touching, knees skimming, heads close. By the time I flopped into bed, I was flush with possibility. I was also quite drunk.

headline: Germany Wants More Women in Politics. But Quotas Are a Bad Idea.
abstract: Forced parity is fundamentally antidemocratic.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Women in Germany won the right to vote in 1918, but a century later they still do not enjoy equal representation. Though the country is led by a woman — who will, most likely, be succeeded by another woman — fewer than a third of the members of the federal Parliament, the Bundestag, are female.

headline: Dick Miller, 90, Dies; Character Actor and Roger Corman Mainstay
abstract: He appeared in dozens of low-budget films for Mr. Corman and later in “The Terminator,” “Gremlins” and other movies directed by Corman acolytes.
lead_paragraph: Dick Miller, a character actor whose reputation as a regular in dozens of low-budget movies produced or directed by Roger Corman led to parts in films by acolytes of Mr. Corman like Joe Dante, Martin Scorsese and James Cameron, died on Jan. 30 in Burbank, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Trump Says He Is Not a Target in Investigations, but the Question Is Complicated
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: The deputy attorney general told the president and his legal team that he is not under scrutiny in the Mueller investigation, but his assertion was complicated by prosecutors naming him a subject in a separate inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s assertion that a senior law enforcement official privately gave assurances that he is not under scrutiny in the investigations shadowing him partly served as a defense strategy but also raised new questions about how the Justice Department is conducting the inquiries.

headline: Clash of Giants: UnitedHealth Takes On Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase
abstract: A lawsuit exposes how unnerved major insurers are by the Big Three’s new venture into health care benefits.
lead_paragraph: Inside a federal courtroom in Boston this week, a bit of intrigue has emerged as lawyers try to pry open the secretive plans of a new venture created by three of the world’s most powerful corporations.

headline: Sanford Sylvan, Baritone Who Created Major Opera Roles, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Sylvan brought to life characters in John Adams’s “Nixon in China” and “The Death of Klinghoffer” during a career as a sensitive, eloquent singer.
lead_paragraph: Sanford Sylvan, the American baritone whose introspective eloquence and serene yet commanding presence put him at the center of some of the most important operatic events of recent times, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: McKinsey Advised Purdue Pharma How to ‘Turbocharge’ Opioid Sales, Lawsuit Says
abstract: The disclosures about the consulting firm are part of the Massachusetts attorney general’s suit against the pharmaceutical giant, which is accused of misleading doctors and patients about the safety of the medication.
lead_paragraph: The world’s most prestigious management-consulting firm, McKinsey & Company, has been drawn into a national reckoning over who bears responsibility for the opioid crisis that has devastated families and communities across America.

headline: Andy Hebenton, N.H.L. Ironman with 630 Consecutive Games, Dies at 89
abstract: A stalwart with the New York Rangers, he extended his streak even when he was sent down to the minors. It only ended when he went to his father’s funeral.
lead_paragraph: Andy Hebenton, who never missed a game during eight seasons with the New York Rangers and a final season with the Boston Bruins in setting a record at the time of 630 consecutive National Hockey League appearances, died on Tuesday in Gresham, Ore. He was 89.

headline: After Critical Report, Police Commissioner Pushes for More Sunlight on Disciplinary Files
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Commissioner James P. O’Neill said a law that keeps police disciplinary records secret “must change” after a report criticized his department’s record on transparency.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the records of police officers who have been disciplined for sundry reasons — from beating up suspects, to making false arrests, to drinking on the job — have been wrapped in secrecy.

keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Border Barriers', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to use his State of the Union address on Tuesday night to outline a bipartisan and optimistic vision of the country, a senior administration official said on Friday.

headline: Huddled in a Brooklyn Jail’s Cells Without Heat

lead_paragraph: More than a thousand inmates at a federal jail in Brooklyn are said to have had limited heat and power for at least this week, when the temperature plummeted to 2 degrees in New York.

headline: Justice Alito Temporarily Blocks a Louisiana Abortion Law

Alito Jr. issued an order on Friday blocking a Louisiana abortion law from taking effect until Thursday. The law, which had been set to go into effect on Monday, could severely limit the number of doctors authorized to perform abortions in the state.

headline: Michael Avenatti Will Not Be Charged With Domestic Violence, Officials Say
abstract: Mr. Avenatti, the lawyer for an adult film star suing President Trump, will not face charges over allegations made by an ex-girlfriend last year.

headline: Eyelash-Freezing Cold, Snow and Early Cherry Blossoms
abstract: Extreme weather has taken two very different forms in some parts of Canada this week. The Times’s climate writers have helped make senses of its causes.
lead_paragraph: Although I live in Ottawa, a city regularly visited by cold snaps, I was still a little unnerved recently while driving to an assignment along an isolated stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway near Deep River, Ontario. The thermometer on the car’s dashboard showed minus 34 Celsius, a good 10 to 15 degrees below normal temperatures for late January in the area.

headline: How to Talk Presidential
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: You can be the political life of the party.
lead_paragraph: Cory Booker is running for president. That makes nine announced candidates for the Democratic primary, and if you add everyone The Times lists from likely to “might,” you’re up to 22.

headline: The Harm in Hustle Culture
abstract: At the heart of homogenization lies emptiness. Anything-but-this anger follows.
lead_paragraph: I read the paper the other day, a satisfying two-hour meander across the world, full of surprises, diversions and revelations. Of course newspapers are dying. This sort of unfocused experience has nothing to do with efficiency or squeezing the last drop of productivity from each minute. It may assuage the soul but is alien to the demands of contemporary hustle culture.

headline: This Is That Song From ‘Russian Doll’
abstract: Harry Nilsson’s “Gotta Get Up” appears at least 10 different times in Natasha Lyonne’s darkly comic series. Here’s why.

headline: Howard Schultz Derangement Syndrome
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Third-Party Politics (US)']
abstract: The left’s war on centrism bodes ill for Democratic chances in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schultz of Starbucks fame told “60 Minutes” on Sunday that he was “seriously thinking” about an independent bid for the presidency, and boy oh boy are liberals and progressives unhappy with the idea. The lifelong Democrat has suddenly morphed, in the eyes of his new detractors, into a vainglorious upstart, entitled rich guy, and potential spoiler who could hand the election to Donald Trump.

headline: Outré
abstract: David Steinberg roots around and comes up with a tough Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —  Lo, and behold this cute little snowflake grid from David Steinberg. The longest entries are but seven letters, and I feel I shall make short work of it. Said I before I’d dug in at all, let alone too deep.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Gimlet in a Quest for More Podcasts
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Podcasts', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Music']
abstract: The music streaming service sees podcasts as a way to increase profits and reduce its reliance on record labels, and Gimlet Media’s hits include “StartUp” and “Homecoming.”
lead_paragraph: Spotify is in advanced talks to buy the podcast studio Gimlet Media, according to two people briefed on the proposed deal, a move that could help the music streaming service improve its profit margins and reduce its dependence on the major record companies.

headline: Our Tokyo Bureau Chief on Where She Finds ‘Bolts of Insight’ (Hint: It’s Outside the Office)
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Careers and Professions', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The Reader Center talks to Motoko Rich about Japanese culture, her stress antidote and children’s novels.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center has started a new series of short interviews, Behind the Byline, to introduce you to Times journalists. Is there a reporter, photographer or editor whom you would like to get to know? Tell us in the comments section.

headline: Corrections: February 2, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, February 2, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day: Cory Booker Announces Presidential Bid, Joining Most Diverse Field Ever
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 2, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “It shows the growth of the country and that many of us who have struggled for civil and human rights feel that we are in a new moment that we wanted.”

headline: Adventure in a Wedding Dress
abstract: For a year, this bride traveled the world, with her wedding dress in tow. After her actual wedding day, she stepped into the dress 50 more times, zippering up the back and taking photographs — in 33 different countries, including Spain, Greece, Israel and Seychelles.
lead_paragraph: You spent months searching for the perfect wedding dress — only to wear it for one special day. Zoe Aust had a different idea. Ms. Aust, 27, was determined, she said, to get her “money’s worth” from her gown. After her wedding Dec. 31, 2017 at the Westmount Country Club in Woodland Park, N.J., she and her husband, Nick Aust, 24, quit their jobs and cashed out their savings to embark on an unconventional honeymoon. She had an epiphany while talking with a family member about wearing her wedding dress only once: “Why not bring along the dress that makes me feel so beautiful to the most beautiful places in the world?” The couple documented their travels on their blog and Instagram account, “Marry Me In Travel.” Ms. Aust, who purchased a Watters Ferrera gown at a trunk show at the Bridal Garden, a bridal boutique in Evesham Township, N.J., captured the attention of many including the style team at Watters. “We loved following their journey and seeing how they styled Ferrera,” said Sydney Watters Dunbar the company’s style director. “We are always inspired by our brides, but Nick and Zoe took this to a new level.”

headline: Super Bowl Pitches That Aren’t ‘SOO Good!’
abstract: The marketing blitz of the Super Bowl, seemingly unending and often head-shaking, is an excuse to promote just about anything.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Super Bowl is a bonanza for brands, advertisers and influencers. The prospect of attaching even the most unrelated product to the biggest television spectacle of the year means marketers are out hawking massage chairs, avocados and social media apps as somehow the perfect Super Bowl #content.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Pick of the Litter’ and ‘Bordertown’
abstract: A feel-good movie about guide dogs in training hits Hulu. And the second season of a Finnish crime drama debuts on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: A feel-good movie about guide dogs in training hits Hulu. And the second season of a Finnish crime drama debuts on Netflix.

headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
abstract: It’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the stories you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: From foreign policy developments to the growing 2020 primary field, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

headline: Taliban to Meet Afghan Politicians (but Not Ghani) in Moscow
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani’s Afghan government has been shut out of the insurgents’ peace talks with the United States, and the meeting in Russia could undermine him further.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban are expected to meet with Afghan opposition leaders in Moscow in the coming days, a development that could further undermine the government of President Ashraf Ghani, which has found itself excluded from the talks seeking an end to the 17-year war.

headline: Apps and Services to Help You Get Around on Your Next Trip
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Whether you’re traveling abroad or just away from home, these apps and services can help you get from the airport or hotel to the places you actually want to see.
lead_paragraph: The first challenge you face on arriving somewhere new is usually how to get around, but the right technology can make it easier. There are tools suited to specific destinations, or to modes of transport, whether you want to hail a ride in Tel Aviv, explore Paris by scooter or catch a bus from Bangkok to Chiang Mai.

headline: Hidden Gems: Do the Patriots Find Them or Create Them?
abstract: Unexpectedly superb performances by waiver-wire pickups and low draft picks have become a signature of the Bill Belichick era.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In 2000, Antowain Smith, a running back who had been the Buffalo Bills’ first-round draft pick three years earlier, was unceremoniously cut by the team. Smith had been buried on the Bills’ bench.

headline: He Committed Murder. Then He Graduated From an Elite Law School. Would You Hire Him as Your Attorney?
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Legal Profession', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A bipartisan consensus has taken hold: After prison, nonviolent offenders should get a second chance at normal lives. But what about someone whose criminal history — and ambitions — are more extreme?
lead_paragraph: Last September, a group of academics and activists gathered at Princeton University to discuss the limits of artificial intelligence in public policy.

headline: As West Bank Violence Surges, Israel Is Silent on Attacks by Jews
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Israel’s government has been reluctant to condemn attacks by Jewish settlers, wary of alienating the movement’s supporters in an election year.
lead_paragraph: AL MUGHAYIR, West Bank — A gang of a dozen or so armed Jewish settlers descended from a hilltop outpost to the Palestinian village below and opened fire, witnesses said. Israeli soldiers arrived, and instead of stopping the settlers, the witnesses said, they either stood by or clashed with the villagers.

headline: Venezuelans Opposed to Maduro Pour Into Streets for Day of Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Opposition leaders hope to capitalize on international pressure against the authoritarian rule of Venezuela’s president.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan opposition supporters poured into the streets on Saturday, heeding a call from their leaders to stage another day of peaceful protests against President Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian rule in hopes of capitalizing on international pressure to force him from power.

headline: Hershey Says ‘Manufacturing Process’ Is to Blame for Missing Tips on Kisses
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Social Media', 'Chocolate']
abstract: The missing tips were an unwelcome surprise for many chocolate lovers over the holiday season. The problem should be solved in a few months, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate-loving aesthetes can take heart: The mystery of the tipless Hershey’s Kisses has been solved.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: El Chapo’s wife has no regrets. New Overlooked obituaries. Lorena Bobbitt speaks. So does Trump. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend and to February. There are towels to be folded and socks to be matched. There are books to read and travel plans to hatch. No matter what you’re up to, make time for some incredible journalism.

headline: For N.F.L. Retirees, Opioids Bring More Pain
abstract: A brutal game got them hooked on painkillers. In retirement, they battle addiction. The opioid crisis courses through football.
lead_paragraph: Earl Campbell, a former All-Pro running back in the N.F.L., said the first painkillers he took came in a small brown packet that a trainer gave him on the team plane. The former lineman Aaron Gibson received his first painkillers in his rookie year after undergoing shoulder surgery. Randy Grimes, a former center, started taking Vicodin and Halcion, a sleeping pill, in his second season to get through full-contact practices.

headline: Japan’s Working Mothers: Record Responsibilities, Little Help From Dads
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Working Hours', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Discrimination', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Men in Japan do fewer hours of housework and child care than in any of the world’s richest nations. That keeps women from getting better jobs and holds back the economy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The paperwork never ends for Yoshiko Nishimasa.

headline: Woman Killed by Fire in Menstruation Hut, as Nepal Fights a Tradition
abstract: Despite a ban and efforts to educate Nepalese about a centuries-old practice of banishing menstruating women to isolated huts, the tradition stubbornly lives on.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Parbati Bogati knew what to do when her period came.

headline: Julia Cameron Wants You to Do Your Morning Pages
abstract: With “The Artist’s Way,” Julia Cameron invented the way people renovate the creative soul.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — On any given day, someone somewhere is likely leading an Artist’s Way group, gamely knocking back the exercises of “The Artist’s Way” book, the quasi-spiritual manual for “creative recovery,” as its author Julia Cameron puts it, that has been a lodestar to blocked writers and other artistic hopefuls for more than a quarter of a century. There have been Artist’s Way clusters in the Australian outback and the Panamanian jungle; in Brazil, Russia, the United Kingdom and Japan; and also, as a cursory scan of Artist’s Way Meetups reveals, in Des Moines and Toronto. It has been taught in prisons and sober communities, at spiritual retreats and New Age centers, from Esalen to Sedona, from the Omega Institute to the Open Center, where Ms. Cameron will appear in late March, as she does most years. Adherents of “The Artist’s Way” include the authors Patricia Cornwell and Sarah Ban Breathnach. Pete Townshend, Alicia Keys and Helmut Newton have all noted its influence on their work.

headline: Diversity in Big Law and the Attack on Jussie Smollett
abstract: Race/Related is a weekly newsletter focused on race, society and identity, with provocative stories from around The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

headline: Postcards From Your Favorite Hometown Running Spots
abstract: Needs some run-spiration? Here are some of the spectacular places that brighten our readers’ everyday running routes.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Brexit Fight Over Gibraltar Flares Up in an E.U. Footnote
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: European diplomats referred to the territory as “a colony of the British crown,” language that backs Spain’s position in a long-running dispute. Britain was not amused.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Gibraltar, the tiny British territory at the tip of southern Spain, has been so far little more than a footnote in the tense negotiations over Britain’s planned departure from the European Union.

headline: 5 Soldiers and 3 ISIS-Linked Militants Killed in Clashes in Philippines
abstract: The gun battles occurred on Saturday in the southern Philippine island of Jolo, six days after a church attack left 22 dead, the military said.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Five soldiers and three members of Abu Sayyaf, a militant group linked to the Islamic State, were killed in a gun battle on Saturday on the southern Philippine island of Jolo, six days after a church bombing linked to the group left 22 dead, the military said.

headline: Events Are the New Magazines
keywords: ['Magazines', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Parties (Social)', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: And Nicole Vecchiarelli and Andrea Oliveri, the founders of an agency called Special Projects, are here to celebrify them.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday evening, Jordan Roth, a Broadway producer of “Angels in America” and “Kinky Boots,” was serving as the M.C. of a party hosted by Town & Country magazine on the top floor of the Standard Hotel in downtown Manhattan. Wearing sequined pants and a jeweled hairpin, he kvelled with Kelly Ripa, dressed in blue velvet.

headline: After a ‘Redo’ Reunion, They Rediscovered Their Chemistry
abstract: The couple, who split up in the 1980s, got back together 29 years later, after a nudge by the bride.
lead_paragraph: Corina Biton and Gary Steven Blicksilver are to be married Feb. 3 at Costa d’Este Beach Resort and Spa in Vero Beach, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Hadar is to officiate.

headline: A Deadly River of Mud: Video of Brazil Dam Collapse Emerges
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Missing Persons', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Footage released a week after the tragedy showed how the dam released 2.5 billion gallons of brown sludge that buried people, cars and buildings in seconds.
lead_paragraph: A week after a dam burst at a mine in southeastern Brazil, killing at least 115 people and leaving 248 others missing, new images and video footage have emerged showing the exact moment of the collapse.

headline: An Urgent Call for Compromise in Venezuela
abstract: The risk of a winner-takes-all approach in the country’s political crisis is extraordinary. It’s time to seek a negotiated transition.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two weeks, the United States, with the support of several countries in Latin America, has recognized the government of Juan Guaidó, the president of Venezuela’s National Assembly, and given it control over the country’s oil revenues. By doing so, it has entered a dangerous game of chicken with the Venezuelan military: Abandon President Nicolás Maduro or face the devastation of the Venezuelan economy. The message is stark: Change regime or starve.

headline: In the Pale of Winter, Trump’s Tan Remains a State Secret
keywords: ['Suntan', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The White House insists that only “good genes” and a clear powder are behind President Trump’s glow, but mysteries about his grooming routine abound.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trees in the capital are barren, spindly things. The temperature has dipped, requiring puffy coats. With the government open — for now — President Trump has left the frigidity of governing for a weekend in Palm Beach.

headline: Does My Apartment Have to Be So Hot in the Winter?
abstract: A New York City apartment can feel downright tropical when it’s cold outside. But there are ways to cool it down.
lead_paragraph: Q: My apartment in a 14-story co-op in Long Island City, Queens, is consistently overheated. I have complained several times to management, as have others. But whatever comfort ensues lasts barely a day before the apartments overheat again. Even with windows open, the temperature in my foyer gets as high as 82 degrees, and higher near the baseboards and risers. I have lived in this building for 15 years and this is the most uncomfortable winter I’ve spent here. What can I do?

headline: Virginia Governor, Ralph Northam, Defies Calls to Resign Over Racist Photo
abstract: Mr. Northam denied that he appeared in Ku Klux Klan robes or in blackface in a yearbook photo, but revealed that he darkened his face for a costume on another occasion in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Gov. Ralph Northam of Virginia, defying pleas from his own party to resign, said on Saturday that he would remain in office, and flatly denied that he had worn Ku Klux Klan robes or appeared in blackface in an image from his medical school yearbook that has upended his governorship and embarrassed his fellow Democrats.

headline: Russia Pulls Out of I.N.F. Treaty in ‘Symmetrical’ Response to U.S. Move
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Treaties', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Russia will no longer observe the 1987 nuclear pact, which the Trump administration suspended on Friday. China urged both powers to observe the agreement, but showed no interest in joining it.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in a decision that was widely expected, suspended his country’s observance of a key nuclear arms control pact on Saturday in response to a similar move by the United States a day before.

headline: 29 of Our Most Delicious Dips
abstract: Perfect for snacking on the couch, with or without a football game.
lead_paragraph: Curl up on the couch, turn on the TV and snack on Buffalo chicken dip (above), seven-layer dip, lemony whipped feta or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: A Mayor’s Effort to Play Down Henry Ford’s Anti-Semitism Backfires
abstract: The mayor of Dearborn, Mich., halted distribution of a city history magazine documenting Ford’s bigoted views, a move that riled residents and historians.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Henry Ford is everywhere in Dearborn, Mich., his hometown, where more than 70 years after the famed industrialist’s death, his name or likeness graces everything from the performing arts center to the manhole covers.

headline: Trump Sought a Loan During the 2016 Campaign. Deutsche Bank Said No.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Donald Trump turned to the German bank, one of the few lenders willing to do business with him, to borrow millions of dollars that would go to his golf resort in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was burning through cash.

headline: One Way to Make College Meaningful
abstract: Don’t find yourself; find a vocation.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “vocational education” might conjure up an image of trade schools that train students to work in traditionally blue-collar jobs. There is a growing movement, however, found largely among private and religiously affiliated colleges and universities, to focus on vocation as it evolves from the Christian tradition, in the sense of a “calling.”

headline: Medicare for All Emerges as Early Policy Test for 2020 Democrats
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Taxation']
abstract: Many liberals who are influential in the presidential primaries want a single-payer system, but some voters are uneasy about losing private insurance. Most candidates are now walking fine lines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren spoke at length this week about her vision for improving the American health care system, like strengthening the Affordable Care Act and making prescription drugs more affordable. Twice, though, she ignored a question posed to her: Would she support eliminating private health insurance in favor of a single-payer system?

headline: This Super Bowl Is Not Everyone’s Bowl of Chips
abstract: St. Louis is angry the Rams left. New Orleans thinks the Saints got cheated. Los Angeles has the Rams, but hey, LeBron is back. Atlanta is the conflicted host.
lead_paragraph: Some cities are not all in on the Super Bowl this year. And those places include the city where the game is being held and the city that one of the two teams calls home.

headline: Chamber of Commerce Decides Bipartisanship Is Good Business
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce revamps its political scoring system as frustrated business groups try to foster more across-the-aisle solutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Chamber of Commerce took a close look at its congressional report card and gave itself a failing grade.

headline: T.S.A. Agent at Orlando Airport Jumps to His Death From Hotel Balcony
abstract: The terminal was evacuated after the unidentified man jumped, causing passengers to flee unscreened into restricted areas.
lead_paragraph: A terminal at Orlando International Airport was evacuated and incoming flights were grounded on Saturday morning after a Transportation Security Administration officer jumped to his death, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, Next in Line, Draws a Spotlight
abstract: If Gov. Ralph Northam accedes to his party’s calls to resign, Justin Fairfax would become the second African-American governor in the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: This article was published before a college professor said that Justin Fairfax sexually assaulted her in 2004; he has denied the allegation. Read about her statement here and the latest on Virginia’s political upheaval here.

headline: Why Can’t Rich People Save Winter?
keywords: ['Skiing', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Ski season is shrinking. Yet the people who love the sport aren’t doing enough to stop climate change.
lead_paragraph: From the snow-dusted ridgelines of the Catskills to the rugged summits of the Rocky Mountains, Sierra Nevada and Cascades, winter is slowly disappearing. And snow is receding with it.

headline: My Mother Was a Betting Woman
abstract: She taught me that a gamble ought not be reckless. The bigger the risk, the bigger your purpose needs to be.
lead_paragraph: Every night in my childhood home, the ritual was the same. We would wait, nervously, for the phone to ring. My mother would pick it up and hear the news: that day’s combination of winning three-digit numbers, which told her whether any of her customers had been lucky. And if any of them had, she would have to pay out their winnings — at a rate of 500 to 1.

headline: Venezuela’s Very Normal Revolution
abstract: For more than a decade, I have been fighting against a government. Now I am fighting for one.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — It was a sunny Friday afternoon in a town square. A pleasant breeze rustled the leaves of the palm trees that shaded crowds of people waiting around a small, open-air stage. The president squeezed through the tightly packed audience, stood before a lectern, and gave a brief, reassuring speech before hundreds of smiling onlookers. Then he took questions from reporters, and after joining the crowd in singing the national anthem, left.

headline: The Real Legacy of the 1970s
abstract: Forget leisure suits and disco balls. The decade’s economic tumult changed who Americans were as a people.
lead_paragraph: In most histories of how Americans became so polarized, the Great Inflation of the 1970s is given short shrift — sometimes no shrift at all. This is wrong. Inflation was as pivotal a factor in our national crackup as Vietnam and Watergate.

headline: When the Suffrage Movement Sold Out to White Supremacy
abstract: African-American women were written out of the history of the woman suffrage movement. As the centennial of the 19th Amendment approaches, it’s time for a new look at the past.
lead_paragraph: Americans are being forced to choose between a cherished lie and a disconcerting truth as they prepare to celebrate the centennial of the 19th Amendment in 2020. The lie holds that the amendment ended a century-long struggle by guaranteeing women the right to vote. The truth is that it barred states from denying voting rights based on gender but “guaranteed” nothing. More than a dozen states had already granted millions of women voting rights before ratification, and millions of other women — particularly African-Americans in the Jim Crow South — remained shut out of the polls for decades afterward.

headline: Janet Napolitano on DACA’s Enduring Legacy
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)']
abstract: As secretary of homeland security, she signed the memorandum that created the popular program protecting ‘Dreamers.’ Now she’s fighting to save it.
lead_paragraph: For all his efforts to undo the work of the prior administration, President Trump’s most striking failure has been his attempt to reverse the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program — a reprieve from deportation President Barack Obama issued nearly seven years ago to undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children.

headline: The Church and the Abortion Capital
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How Catholicism's decline increased partisan polarization on abortion.
lead_paragraph: In a sense it’s not surprising that a renewed debate about abortion would begin in New York State, which passed a law last week — since imitated, to more controversy, by Virginia Democrats — ratifying the right to kill human beings in utero in the third trimester.

headline: The Age of Big Leaks
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Panama Papers', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A terabyte of data — 100 million pages or 1,000 hours of video — can be shared on a thumb drive. But stolen secrets come with complications.
lead_paragraph: On the very day that Roger Stone was charged with lying about a momentous set of leaks that originated with Russian hackers, a feisty band of transparency activists led by a Boston woman posted a voluminous collection of leaks from inside Russia.

headline: Instagram’s Sneakiness Makes Super Bowl Ads Look Quaint
abstract: When the commercials come on during the game, at least you’ll know Jason Bateman is trying to sell you something.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, millions of Americans will hunker down in front of the nearest big screen to watch the Super Bowl and its roster of splashy, celebrity-studded advertisements. For brands, it’s a crucial stage: In our extremely fragmented media landscape, there’s no better way to reach a crowd.

headline: Let Children Get Bored Again
abstract: Boredom teaches us that life isn’t a parade of amusements. More important, it spawns creativity and self-sufficiency.
lead_paragraph: “I’m bored.” It’s a puny little phrase, yet it has the power to fill parents with a cascade of dread, annoyance and guilt. If someone around here is bored, someone else must have failed to enlighten or enrich or divert. And how can anyone — child or adult — claim boredom when there’s so much that can and should be done? Immediately.

headline: Casting Their Votes by Voting Their Caste
abstract: In rural India, old class divisions still rule local politics. Will this spell trouble for Narendra Modi?
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in India in the 1970s and ’80s, my father’s job as a naval officer took our family from one big city to another, from Bombay to Singapore. But every summer, we spent a month with my maternal grandparents in Bijnor, a small city in Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, and one of its poorest.

headline: Is This the Right Way to End a War?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: Many experts worry that the U.S. is repeating the mistakes of Vietnam in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan long ago took from Vietnam the title of America’s longest war, when it passed the 13-year mark in 2014.

headline: The Meaning of Tony Romo, Super Bowl Psychic
abstract: Meet Romostradamus. Savor Romomania. And behold the beauty of real expertise in a country starved of it.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl arrives and, with it, so many questions big and small. Is Tom Brady part cyborg and maybe even immortal? Will the Los Angeles Rams be hamstrung by the knowledge that they got this far by the grace of several sleepwalking referees?

headline: How Silicon Valley Puts the ‘Con’ in Consent
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Software']
abstract: If no one reads the terms and conditions, how can they continue to be the legal backbone of the internet?
lead_paragraph: The average person would have to spend 76 working days reading all of the digital privacy policies they agree to in the span of a year. Reading Amazon’s terms and conditions alone out loud takes approximately nine hours.

headline: A Design to Bring Life to Death
abstract: A special section in the Sunday paper paid tribute to extraordinary black men and women who were left out of The Times’s obituaries when they died. Its design aims to bring joy to readers.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: To Build a Champion, the Rams Took Risks. They Just Don’t See It That Way.
abstract: Los Angeles bet on the team’s culture, and its research, when adding Aqib Talib, Ndamukong Suh, Dante Fowler and Marcus Peters to bolster the defense. It helped the Rams make the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Marcus Peters came into this week well aware of the narrative that had developed around himself and the other defensive starters the Los Angeles Rams had acquired since last season.

headline: El Chapo Drugged and Raped 13-Year-Old Girls, Witness Claims
abstract: On Friday night, prosecutors in the trial of El Chapo unsealed several secret documents, some of which revealed allegations that the kingpin had drugged and raped young girls.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors at the trial of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera spent more than 10 weeks painting the kingpin as the most despicable sort of criminal. Mr. Guzmán, known as El Chapo, trafficked tons of drugs, bribed nearly everyone of authority in Mexico and once ordered his henchmen to incinerate the bodies of two of his enemies in a bonfire, they said.

headline: Candice Payne Got 30 Hotel Rooms for Homeless People in Chicago During Severe Cold Snap
abstract: She said it was a spur-of-the-moment decision. Her efforts gained widespread attention, grew and helped house more than 100 homeless people.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures plunged to life-threatening lows this week, more than 100 homeless people in Chicago unexpectedly found themselves with food, fresh clothes and a place to stay after a local real estate broker intervened.

headline: Virginia Democratic Party in Crisis as Officials Face Scandals
abstract: The governor and attorney general acknowledged wearing blackface in the past, and the lieutenant governor faced an allegation of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: The governor and attorney general acknowledged wearing blackface in the past, and the lieutenant governor faced an allegation of sexual assault.

headline: Ejection Letters
abstract: Natan Last, let’s go to the videotape.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Natan Last has a tremendous record for introducing elegant new entries (how had we lived without CAFFEINE FIX?) and a sharp eye for the type of wordplay that sneaks up on you (and, if you’re me, keeps right on going, just overhead). This is one of those puzzles. The solve is greatly enhanced by today’s constructor notes, so glean what details you can from Mr. Last — he mentors, and teaches people how to do this stuff, and has the type of loopy and flexible mind that slots together intricate bits and pieces to form a cohesive whole. It’s quite amazing.

headline: When Blackface Photos Cause Political Storms
abstract: From New York to Florida to California, politicians have gotten in hot water in recent years over racially offensive images. Here are some examples.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ralph Northam of Virginia is the latest and most prominent political figure to be engulfed in controversy over the wearing of blackface or other racially offensive imagery, but hardly the only one.

headline: Protesters Try to Storm Brooklyn Jail With Little Heat or Electricity

lead_paragraph: Which kind of Super Bowl watcher are you? One who A) cares about the actual game, B) is in it for the snacks, or C) wants to see how the $5.3 million ads stack up? That’s the top asking price for a 30-second commercial during CBS’s broadcast, although some spots are going for the relative steal of $5.1 million. (Oh, and if you’re wondering, I’m a solid C, plus B if spicy wings are available.) This is the first year in a decade that the cost of a Super Bowl ad hasn’t increased — NBC charged $5.25 million in 2018 — mostly owing to waning viewer numbers. You can drop that factoid when the cheese-dip conversation hits a lull, or any of the other business and tech tidbits you’re about to devour in this email. You can have a nachos-and-beer hangover on Monday and still be on top of the news.

Cut just so, and arranged on the plate like a movie star at the beach, the sandwich is, as Tejal Rao wrote for The Times this week, “both delicious and alarmingly pretty.” Of course she got us the recipe (above).

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 3, Episode 5: A Convenient ‘Altercation’
abstract: The melee that ended last week’s episode tied a neat little bow on the original investigation. Twenty-five years later, it’s coming undone.

There are important revelations about what ended the investigation in 1980, new wrinkles to its reopening a decade later and a gathering of elderly forces to revisit it again 25 years after that. For the first episode since the opening two, the show gathered power from a meaningful convergence of timelines and the dysfunction of a community more interested in closure than in getting the facts right.

She felt our pain, you might say, but she denied her own.

headline: How Bauhaus Redefined What Design Could Do for Society
abstract: A century after its founding, the German school of art and architecture remains one of the most transcendent — and frustrating — movements of the Modernist age.
lead_paragraph: ON APRIL 11, 1933, the architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe stepped off the tram in the Steglitz neighborhood in southwest Berlin, crossed a bridge and found that his place of work had been surrounded by the police. The Bauhaus, where he taught and served as the director, had occupied an old telephone factory building there since 1932. The school first opened in Weimar in 1919, as a place for uniting craftsmanship with the arts in the service of architecture; over time, it changed, becoming more about uniting art with industrial techniques. Once Mies took over the directorship in 1930, it became almost purely a school for architecture.

headline: Italian Alpine Spas, Where Sports Are an Afterthought
abstract: The South Tyrol has become a modern wellness destination, where tranquillity imposes itself and soothing waters call.
lead_paragraph: A paradise for skiers, the Italian Alps of South Tyrol offer a more placid pastime that’s surging anew. A host of spas are sprouting up in isolated tracts among the highlands, and though there’s hiking, biking and access to some of the Alps’ easier ski slopes, sports are a mere afterthought here. The spas draw skiers and nonskiers alike to spend days soaking in hot tubs, besotted by the view of these commanding, ice-shrouded peaks.

headline: To Avoid a Recession, Start Spending Now
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Congress should give the economy a bump. Once a slowdown begins, it will be too late.
lead_paragraph: The strong economic growth of mid-2018 — the stock market soared, hiring picked up and consumer spending surged — reflected, in part, the benefits of a boost in fiscal stimulus. The Trump administration pushed for, and got, a huge tax cut, and then, to give the economy even more oomph, Congress passed budgets for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 that included a rare bipartisan agreement to juice spending for defense and social programs. But the effects of all that stimulus are starting to wane, and problems are emerging that make a recession in 2020 look more and more likely.

headline: The Gift of Shared Grief
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Letters', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Grief (Emotion)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: It’s hard to know what to say to people in mourning. Say something anyway.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When my mother died in 2012, she left behind a huge collection of memorabilia. Not just the usual love letters, family photographs and cherished recipe cards but also random items that almost no one else bothers to save. Parking tickets. Embossed cocktail napkins from the weddings of people I’ve never heard of. An Alabama Power bill from 1972. Things that meant something to her but whose meaning she never explained to me.

headline: It Took Chanel 9 Days and a Team of 150 to Build an Indoor Beach
abstract: The brand’s elaborately staged ready-to-wear shows are a much-anticipated staple of the fashion calendar — and the latest one was especially transporting.
lead_paragraph: At Chanel’s most recent spring ready-to-wear collection, held in Paris’s Grand Palais on an overcast morning last October, nearly 3,000 guests were transported to Sylt, a tiny German island in the North Sea, where Karl Lagerfeld, the house’s longtime artistic director, first remembers encountering the ocean as a child. The nave of the late 19th-century, 828,220-square-foot exhibition hall was, save for its vaulted glass ceiling, encased with a cotton backdrop depicting a blue sky flecked with fluffy clouds. Then, one by one, 80 barefoot models — some with sandals dangling from their hands — began to walk down a runway of sand while real-water waves crashed gently on the artificial shore.

headline: The Putin I Knew; the Putin I Know
abstract: I met Vladimir Putin and trusted him in the early 1990s, when he was deputy mayor of St. Petersburg. Now that he’s Russia’s president, he’s different. He’s no friend of democracy.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin of Russia celebrated the New Year by having an American tourist, Paul Whelan, arrested as a spy. Mr. Whelan was in Moscow to attend a wedding. But Mr. Putin needed a hostage as a potential trade for a Russian woman with Kremlin connections — Maria Butina, who had pleaded guilty of conspiring with a Russian official “to establish unofficial lines of communication with Americans having power and influence over U.S. politics.” So Mr. Putin grabbed Mr. Whelan, who has not been released.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries that stumped solvers in last week’s puzzles.
lead_paragraph: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, known familiarly as R.P.I., is a university located in Troy, N.Y., and is known primarily for its engineering and technology programs. It was also located in Emily Carrol’s crossword on Jan. 30, where it was missed by a large number of solvers.

headline: Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Virginia Denounces Sexual Assault Allegation as a ‘Smear’
abstract: Aides to Fairfax, a Democrat who has drawn national attention as Gov. Ralph Northam considers resigning over past racist behavior, said the allegation was false and unsubstantiated.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Virginia emphatically denied on Monday a woman’s claim that he sexually assaulted her in 2004, suggesting at one point that Gov. Ralph Northam’s supporters were trying to block his ascent to the governorship at a moment when Mr. Northam is besieged by demands that he resign over charges of racism.

headline: Northam Scandal Opens Rift Between Top Democrats in Virginia
abstract: As a racist yearbook photo and claims of sexual assault plunged the capitol deeper into turmoil, the state’s lieutenant governor suggested the governor might be trying to sabotage him.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Virginia plunged deeper into political turmoil Monday as Gov. Ralph Northam told aides he was not planning to step down, and his own lieutenant governor suggested Mr. Northam’s supporters were behind an effort to smear him with claims of sexual assault to block his ascent if the governor resigned.

headline: Valtellina, Another Side of Nebbiolo
abstract: Next month we will explore these cousins of Barolo and Barbaresco grown in the hills of the Lombardy region of Italy.
lead_paragraph: We now return you to your regular Wine School programming.

headline: Supermarket Wines Are Poured, and Worlds Collide
abstract: An exercise in understanding resulted in outrage, disparagement and general unhappiness. Can anything positive come of it?
lead_paragraph: Well, that seems to have struck a nerve.

headline: Cleaner Classrooms and Rising Scores: With Tighter Oversight, Head Start Shows Gains
keywords: ['Head Start Program', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The improvements made by the country’s biggest preschool program offer a story of bipartisan progress at odds with its polarizing time.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — When federal officials inspected this city’s Head Start program five years ago, they found moldy classrooms, exposed wires, leaking sewage, a sagging roof and trash-strewn playgrounds littered with safety hazards. A teacher had jerked a student so hard she dislocated the girl’s shoulder.

headline: A Writer Describes Palestinian Cuisine, and the World Around It
abstract: Yasmin Khan’s new cookbook, “Zaitoun,” documents her travels in the West Bank and Gaza, and the beauty of the food she encountered there.
lead_paragraph: In November 2016, when the cookbook author Yasmin Khan returned to her home in London after the olive harvest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, she faced a problem: No matter how strenuously she tried, she could not write.

headline: The Best and the Worst of the Super Bowl Movie Trailers
abstract: Marvel movies like “Captain Marvel” and “Avengers: Endgame” stood out; “Alita,” what were you thinking?
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl LIII was a low-scoring game, and the trailers that debuted during the telecast kept their running times down as well. The ad for the Dwayne Johnson-Jason Statham “Fast & Furious” spinoff, “Hobbs & Shaw,” was a one-minute version of the three-minute trailer that was released online Friday, and most of the other clips ran 30 seconds — or half that, in the case of teasers for “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark.” Here’s this year’s lineup.

headline: Frida Kahlo and a Special Mexican Menu
abstract: Visit the Brooklyn Museum for an exhibit about the artist and a meal from a rotating roster of New York chefs.
lead_paragraph: Alongside the Brooklyn Museum’s exhibit “Frida Kahlo: Appearances Can Be Deceiving” which runs from Feb. 8 through May 12, there will be an elaborate Mexican menu with some specialties devised by consulting guest chefs at the museum’s restaurant, the Norm.  The chef Saul Bolton and Great Performances (a catering and restaurant managing company), who run the restaurant, have invited the chef Sue Torres to kick off the round of special menus with dishes like shrimp flautas, sweet plantain gorditas cakes and pan-roasted marinated red snapper. Following Ms. Torres, the participating chefs will be Carlos and Felipe Arellano of Chela in Park Slope, Justin Bazdarich of Oxomoco in Greenpoint, TJ Steele of Claro in Gowanus and Natalia Mendez of La Morada in Mott Haven, in the Bronx.  Each chef will contribute two to three new dishes to the menu.

headline: Boring Game Plus New Orleans Rebellion Leads to Ratings Drop
keywords: ['Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Football', 'Super Bowl', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )']
abstract: N.F.L. ratings shot up during the regular season, but the game was terrible and folks in New Orleans were really mad.
lead_paragraph: It was the lowest-scoring Super Bowl ever, a universally agreed-upon snoozefest. The halftime show was forgettable. The commercials were tame.

headline: How to Keep Your Skin Moisturized for the Rest of Winter
abstract: Protecting your skin from the elements no longer means layering on uncomfortably thick salves. A new batch of heavy-duty creams are surprisingly light.
lead_paragraph: No matter how diligently you pile on moisturizer, dry skin in winter is “almost inevitable,” admits Dr. Sarah Dolder, a clinical instructor of dermatology at Columbia University in New York. It’s hard to overcome the season’s moisture-depleting elements — biting winds, extreme cold and overactive indoor heating systems — all of which can leave skin parched, she explains. But layering on thick creams is not necessarily the answer. “Unless they are formulated to absorb effectively into the skin’s lipid bi-layer,” Dr. Dolder says, “they will sit on the surface and potentially cause clogging of the pores.” This is especially problematic for sensitive and acne-prone skin types. Fortunately, a new batch of rich-but-not-thick moisturizers now delivers ultra-hydrating ingredients — everything from squalane to plant stem cells — with airy textures.

headline: Gannett Rejects Hostile Bid From Hedge Fund-Backed Group
abstract: The newspaper publisher’s board said the $1.3 billion offer “is not in the best interests of Gannett and its shareholders.” But the fight for control is likely to go on.
lead_paragraph: Gannett, the publisher of USA Today and more than 100 other newspapers across nearly three dozen states, rejected a hostile takeover bid from a hedge fund-backed newspaper group on Monday, kicking off a battle for shareholder votes to determine the future of the company.

headline: A Pour-Over Coffee Maker Stylish Enough for MoMA
abstract: With its efficient design and reusable stainless-steel filter, you might want to skip the coffee shop.
lead_paragraph: The efficient design of this pour-over coffee maker caught the eye of the people who buy goods for the Museum of Modern Art’s shop. With a handle that stays cool, the glass coffee-brewing and serving carafe holds 34 ounces and comes with a reusable stainless-steel filter and a fat cork stopper. It’s all you need to get your coffee fix from morning to dinner party. The pitcher and filter are dishwasher-safe.

headline: Vitamin or Mineral Supplements Don’t Prevent Dementia
abstract: B vitamins; beta carotene; vitamins C, D or E; zinc, copper or selenium — none proved effective in preventing cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: A large review of studies has found no solid evidence that vitamin and mineral supplements have any effect in preventing cognitive decline or dementia.

headline: Set the Dinner Table With Legos
abstract: The owner of the restaurant Pinch Chinese, in SoHo, uses the toy blocks as chopstick rests.
lead_paragraph: Raid the toy box to set the table for your Lunar New Year feast. That’s more or less what Sean Tang did. He’s an owner of Pinch Chinese, a welcoming dim sum (and more) restaurant in SoHo where Legos are used as chopstick rests. He’s a Lego fan and was looking for an unexpected detail, and the result, in collaboration with others involved in the restaurant, was an inspired choice: The tiny bumps on the blocks keep the chopsticks from rolling off.

headline: A Strawberry Cocktail for Valentine’s Day
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: Mix a drink with tequila, crème de cassis and dry sparkling wine.
lead_paragraph: A vibrant cocktail, ruby-red and sparkling, will set the tone for an intimate Valentine’s dinner at home. Called Los Amores and inspired by a Kir Royale, it was created by Patrick Timmis, the beverage director for the Bien Trucha Group, a family-owned Mexican restaurant and catering company in Geneva, Ill., with four places: Bien Trucha, A Toda Madre, Quiubo and Santo Cielo. Muddle two ripe strawberries in a cocktail shaker, add three-fourths ounce each of lime juice and simple syrup, one-quarter ounce of crème de cassis and an ounce of blanco tequila. Shake with ice, strain into a champagne flute, top off with bone-dry sparkling wine and garnish with a strawberry. This makes one drink, but of course you'd prepare enough for two. And consider making more to have refills ready.

headline: Send a Love Letter Full of Chocolates
abstract: A Belgian chocolate company is offering heart-shaped bonbons in a pink folded envelope.
lead_paragraph: Consider Valentine’s Day as a moment for returning to old-fashioned letter writing and sending. Neuhaus, a Belgian chocolate company, has come up with a delectable Valentine Love Letter gift box for the holiday. The pink folded envelope, sealed with a wax stamp, contains heart-shaped bonbons. There are three varieties, each with an exotic touch: dark and white chocolate with crunchy unrefined sugar and Espelette pepper, milk chocolate with Madagascar vanilla and salted caramel, and white chocolate with raspberry and Yunnan green tea. A flyer in the envelope provides details.

headline: L’Avenue Travels From Paris to Saks Fifth Avenue
abstract: A lavish offshoot with the pastry chef Pierre Hermé opens this week.
lead_paragraph: This week’s opening of L’Avenue at Saks, a lavish offshoot of a celebrity magnet in Paris, makes department-store dining feel like an extravagance. The ninth-floor restaurant, in ivory and beige by the designer Philippe Starck, has a varied menu: soups, salads (many with avocado) and dishes like vegan vegetable curry, tiger shrimp, crisp duck, rigatoni with morels, and Dover sole, some with an Asian accent.

headline: The North Magnetic Pole’s Mysterious Journey Across the Arctic
keywords: ['Magnets and Magnetism', 'Earth', 'Navigation', 'Geography', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Global Positioning System', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Scientists accelerated the update of a model of Earth’s fluctuating magnetic field, which is needed to keep navigational systems functioning. Many wondered what’s happening inside the planet’s core.
lead_paragraph: The north magnetic pole is restless.

headline: Saints Beat Patriots in “Super Bowl LIII.”
abstract: And other more exciting scenarios for the dud we watched Sunday night (we know, the Patriots beat the Rams, 13-3)
lead_paragraph: If you sat through Sunday’s football-related entertainment, you could be forgiven for swearing off Super Bowls forever.

headline: Backstreet Boys Get to No. 1 the Way They Used To: By Selling Albums
abstract: Most albums that dominate Billboard’s Top 200 reach the top with million of streams. The boy band’s latest LP, bundled with concert tickets, opened at the top thanks to sales.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Backstreet Boys had a No. 1 album, in fall 2000, CD sales were at their commercial peak and iTunes did not exist; even “American Idol” was still two years away.

headline: Schools in England Introduce a New Subject: Mindfulness
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Education (K-12)', 'Politics and Government', 'Youth', 'Social Media']
abstract: As mental health problems among children increase, the government will try having students practice mindfulness, relaxation and breathing exercises.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Students in England already learn about mathematics, science and history, but hundreds of schools are preparing to expand the traditional curriculum with a new subject: mindfulness.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minorities', 'Slavery (Historical)']

headline: Don McCullin Is a War Photographer. Just Don’t Call Him an Artist.
keywords: ['Photography', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Cold War Era', 'War and Revolution']
abstract: His camera has captured conflict from Northern Ireland to Vietnam. An exhibition at Tate Britain in London shows some of his finest work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “I’m not an artist,” the photographer Don McCullin insisted recently. It was an awkward statement, not least because Mr. McCullin was standing in the Tate Britain gallery in London, in the middle of a major retrospective of his work, which opens Tuesday and runs through May 6.

headline: Elizabeth McCracken’s First Novel in 18 Years Has Whimsy to Spare
abstract: “Bowlaway” revolves around a large cast of characters and a candlepin bowling alley in New England.
lead_paragraph: The greatest bowling scene in American literature, worth slipping on a pair of tricolor slippers to read, is almost certainly the one that opens William Kennedy’s novel “Billy Phelan’s Greatest Game” (1978).

headline: Bob Friend, 88, Mainstay of Pirates Team That Stunned Yanks, Dies
abstract: Mr. Friend was a dependable arm and league standout on losing teams until the 1960 World Series thriller, won by Bill Mazeroski’s walk-off home run.
lead_paragraph: Bob Friend, who learned how to pitch on lowly Pittsburgh Pirate teams of the early 1950s, then became one of the National League’s finest right-handers and an anchor of the team that stunned the Yankees in the thrilling 1960 World Series, was found dead on Sunday at his home in O’Hara Township, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh. He was 88.

headline: The Winning Streak Few Noticed
abstract: Hofstra won 16 straight games and a guard named Justin Wright-Foreman emerged as a star. Someone tell the student body.
lead_paragraph: The University of Tennessee is the top-ranked team in men’s college basketball. The Volunteers have won 16 consecutive games, the longest active winning streak in the country — but only because Hofstra, on Long Island, got upset by Northeastern on Saturday.

headline: China’s Film Industry Finally Joins the Space Race
abstract: Science-fiction movies have been slow to catch on in China, but led by “The Wandering Earth,” a wave of new blockbusters might change that.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China was a latecomer to space exploration, and in the movies, it has been a latecomer to science fiction, too. That is about to change.

abstract: In a new revival, Henry VIII lacks grandeur and Cromwell cunning. Without worthy adversaries, Sir Thomas More’s dilemma never delivers the drama.
lead_paragraph: What is a person of principle to do when the ruler he serves is consumed with reckless vanity?

headline: The Trouble With Autism in Novels
abstract: The disorder is poorly understood. Should novelists be able to make it mean whatever they want?
lead_paragraph: I read every night to my teenage son, who has severe autism. Only recently has he been calm enough to tolerate this, but it’s become an enjoyable ritual. I’m not sure what he understands, yet as I read Helen Macdonald’s memoir, “H Is for Hawk,” about a woman’s year of grief and falconry, J gets a dreamy look on his face. On nights he’s worried I’ll forget, he’ll come to me and demand: “Read bird hawk!”

lead_paragraph: Stacey Abrams’s defeat in the Georgia governor’s race was only a few weeks old when she arrived in New York in December to meet with campaign donors and political allies. At a reception in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood, a supporter asked her what she would do next.

headline: China’s Online Censorship Stifles Trade, Too
keywords: ['Censorship', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: When the Chinese government blocks foreign internet companies for political reasons, the United States should treat the tactic as the anticompetitive economic strategy that it is.
lead_paragraph: As China and the United States engage in high-level negotiations over a possible trade deal, it’s puzzling to see what’s been left off the table: the Chinese internet market. China blocks or hinders nearly every important foreign competitor online, including Google, Facebook, Wikipedia in Chinese, Pinterest, Line (the major Japanese messaging company), Reddit and The New York Times. Even Peppa Pig, a British cartoon character and internet video sensation, has been censored on and off; an editorial in the Communist Party’s official People’s Daily newspaper once warned that she could “destroy children’s youth.”

headline: Rivers Cuomo Prepackages His Internet Presence
abstract: The musician on his platonic Tinder use and his addiction to an audience’s cheer.
lead_paragraph: It has been 25 years since the “Blue Album” was released, and Weezer is having a resurgence. Your album “Pacific Daydream” is nominated for a Grammy this year; you just released the “Teal Album,” and the “Black Album” is coming out in March. Most important, your cover of Toto’s “Africa” hit more than 25 million streams on Spotify. Well, that started with a 14-year-old girl in Ohio who spammed us every day requesting us to cover Toto’s “Africa.” We let it play out for a few months and decided to release Toto’s “Rosanna.” Then, a week later, we put out “Africa.”
