headline: The Political ‘Center’ Isn’t Gone — Just Disputed
abstract: Has political polarization really turned the center into a no man’s land, or is it simply in flux?
lead_paragraph: In politics, the visuals matter. We imagine the electorate in red and blue, solid colors representing a divided country. This fails to capture how Americans actually vote; even in the reddest states, hundreds of thousands of people mark their ballots for Democrats, and vice versa. But our collective imagination puts us in one place or the other: Trump country or Obamaland, home turf or hostile territory.

headline: The Gay History of America’s Classic Children’s Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: From “Frog and Toad” to “Where the Wild Things Are,” many of the most enduring 20th-century titles share a secret language of queer compassion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4/1/20: We’re revisiting this feature, originally published last year, following the death of Tomie dePaola, the author and illustrator of “Strega Nona,” on Monday at 85.

headline: ‘A Light for Me in the Darkness’: For Migrant Detainees, a Bond Forged by Letter
keywords: ['Letters', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Archives and Records', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Residents of San Diego began writing to migrants in an immigration detention center just a few miles away. The letters opened new worlds for both of them.
lead_paragraph: Achiri Nelson Geh, a young activist deeply involved in the independence movement in southern Cameroon, knew he had to flee: Police officers had killed his brother, and they were looking for him. Making his way by plane, boat, bus and foot to Mexico, he surrendered to United States authorities at the border in the hope of winning asylum.

headline: Albany’s ‘Wonder Twins’ Form a Power Duo, Challenging Cuomo’s Influence
abstract: The partnership between Carl Heastie, the Assembly speaker, and Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the Senate majority leader, has led to a shift in Albany.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Two Bedrooms, Almost
abstract: When a pair of friends went looking for a two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn, they learned that what one person calls a bedroom, another might not.
lead_paragraph: As roommate chemistry goes, it’s hard to find a better pair than Caitlin Sikora and Chelsea Retzloff. When the two friends, who are in their early 30s, met through a dance workshop five years ago, they learned that Ms. Sikora had degrees in dance and physics, and Ms. Retzloff had degrees in dance and … chemistry. More recently, both wanted an upgrade from their rundown apartments.

headline: Key West Bans Sunscreen Containing Chemicals Believed to Harm Coral Reefs
abstract: The law’s supporters see it as a crucial step toward protecting the city’s reefs, which draw visitors from around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Key West, the sunny city at the southernmost tip of Florida, voted this week to ban the sale of sunscreen containing chemicals believed to harm coral reefs.

headline: How a Brooklyn Jail Without Heat Inspired So Much Outrage
abstract: Many vulnerable people suffered during last week’s deep freeze. But only the misery at a federal detention center galvanized protesters.
lead_paragraph: Late Monday afternoon, the day after electricity had been restored to the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn and heat had returned, protesters kept at it outside the jail, holding banners and banging on pots and chanting and questioning.

headline: 36 Hours in San Juan
abstract: Puerto Rico’s capital is open for business, welcoming visitors with its winning combination of lovely beaches, energetic night life and gregarious island charm.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year and a half after Hurricane Maria, stories of hope and progress are emerging in Puerto Rico, just as the island’s tropical vegetation is flourishing once again. While there is still much work to be done, and some rural areas might not fully recover for years, the capital of San Juan has been humming along for months. With a few exceptions, shops, hotels and restaurants are operating as usual, and there are some noteworthy additions to the city’s lively dining scene. The cultural landscape is energetic as well: Lin-Manuel Miranda made headlines with his reprisal of the lead role in the musical “Hamilton,” which played at San Juan’s main performing arts center last month, and galleries in Santurce and Old San Juan are showcasing thought-provoking works by local artists. As always, you’ll find picturesque beaches, heady cocktails, contagious music and gregarious locals, more eager than ever to welcome visitors to their sunny corner of the Caribbean.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Miguel Covarrubias’s caricatures; Mariam Ghani and Erin Ellen Kelly’s latest collaboration; Bill Traylor’s drawings; Vivian Maier’s self-portraits; and Hervé Guibert’s photographs of friends and lovers.
lead_paragraph: Although they will overlap only briefly, “Miguel Covarrubias: A Retrospective” is the perfect side dish to the movable feast of the Frida Kahlo exhibition opening Feb. 8 at the Brooklyn Museum. Born in Mexico City in 1904, Covarrubias was a member of Kahlo’s inner circle —  a highly sociable workaholic, painter, anthropologist, teacher, writer and sometime curator — who had a chameleonic talent for drawing. He would illustrate his own books on the ethnography of Mesoamerican Mexico, but arriving in New York, at age 19, he established himself with influential celebrity caricatures for magazines like The New Yorker, Vogue and Vanity Fair. He soon knew everyone who was anyone, figured in the Harlem Renaissance and, briefly in Paris, designed sets for Josephine Baker.

headline: The Prescription Drugs That Rich People Buy
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Income Inequality', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Though the wealthy tend to be healthier and fill fewer prescriptions over all, they’re likelier to purchase medications for some serious diseases.
lead_paragraph: There are many, many things that rich people buy in larger quantities. It turns out medications for certain serious diseases may be one of them.

headline: Racing the Clock, and Climate Change
abstract: A beloved Dutch speedskating race survives by relocating to Austria, where thick ice still beckons. For now.
lead_paragraph: WEISSENSEE, Austria — A thousand Dutch skaters congregated before dawn on the frozen surface of the Weissensee, the long, slender lake that gives this small Austrian mountain town its name. The sky was dark, and the headlamps of the shivering skaters cast a spiritual glow onto the charcoal ice. They had been warned not to remove their goggles, lest their eyeballs frost over in the wind.

headline: Seth Meyers Imagines What We Might Find in Trump’s Childhood Home
abstract: The house is on the market for $3 million. Seth Meyers joked that with a time machine, a visitor to the home could “save the world.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Why a Deal With the Taliban Will Prevent Attacks on America
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Taliban members have come to see Al Qaeda and the Islamic State as threats to their cause.
lead_paragraph: The United States and the Taliban made progress in peace talks in late January after coming to a basic understanding about withdrawing American troops in return for Taliban commitments to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a safe haven for transnational terrorists. An agreement between the United States and the Taliban has been long overdue — as part of a broader settlement also involving the Taliban's Afghan opponents — and is the way out of a war without victory.

headline: Going to College Should Not Be a Financial Albatross
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Student Loans', 'Tuition']
abstract: Our country has most of the best colleges in the world. Students should be able to afford them, and borrowers should not be crushed by debts.
lead_paragraph: A college graduate paying more than $1,000 per month on student loans recently wrote that he had been told “to chase down a bachelor’s degree by any means necessary.” But, he added, “no one mentions just how expensive and soul-crushing the debt will be.”

headline: Why Is the Republican Party So Confused About Health Care?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicare']
abstract: The G.O.P. needs to finally figure out, or at least start figuring out, exactly what it stands for on health care policy.
lead_paragraph: Judging by exit polls, the single most effective midterm issue for Democrats was health care — in particular, the argument, made by Democratic candidates across the country, that Republicans were out to eliminate the Affordable Care Act’s regulations governing pre-existing conditions.

headline: The Overlooked Scandal of Priests Sexually Abusing Nuns
abstract: The pope’s first public acknowledgment of the problem came after decades of allegations worldwide that met with seeming inaction from the Vatican.

abstract: The artist proves her mettle in her first New York show since the 2017 Whitney Biennial.
lead_paragraph: Dana Schutz’s current show at Petzel Gallery is her best in New York in a while, maybe ever.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Some countries could lose quite badly. A few could benefit.
lead_paragraph: Some countries could lose quite badly. A few could benefit.

headline: How British Feminism Became Anti-Trans
abstract: A surprisingly mainstream movement of feminists known as TERFs oppose transgender rights as a symptom of “female erasure.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, two British women stormed onto Capitol Hill in Washington for the purposes of ambushing Sarah McBride, the national press secretary of the Human Rights Campaign.

headline: To Block Aid Organized by Venezuela Opposition, Military Obstructs Highway
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Politics and Government', 'Shortages', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The attempt to deliver desperately needed supplies is a test of strength for both President Nicolás Maduro and his opponents.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan military has blockaded a major highway link with Colombia to prevent opponents of the government from bringing food and medicine into Venezuela, a country gripped by life-threatening shortages and a deepening political crisis.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: BB&T and SunTrust say they plan to join forces, in a deal that values the combined lenders at $66 billion.

headline: Germany Restricts Facebook’s Data Gathering
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Social Media', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Privacy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The competition authority said the company could no longer combine data from different sources without explicit permission from users.
lead_paragraph: In a direct challenge to Facebook’s business model, Germany’s competition authority on Thursday sharply curtailed how the tech giant may profile people, saying that users could refuse to allow the company to combine their Facebook information with data about their activities on other sites.

headline: A Sparkling Shrine to a Reviled Russian Leader
abstract: Boris Yeltsin is widely held responsible in Russia for destroying the Soviet Union. A new museum seeks to counter that image — and subtly rebuke President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has reviled those years as a period of chaos, crime and “total poverty” that “nobody wants to ever see return.”

headline: ‘The Gospel of Eureka’ Review: Christianity and Queerness Intersect in a Small Town
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: This cheerful documentary from Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher refuses to grapple with its glaring contradictions.
lead_paragraph: “The Gospel of Eureka” is only 75 minutes long, yet feels much longer. That’s partly because this cheery documentary — about the uneasy alignment of L.G.B.T. life and avid Christianity in the town of Eureka Springs, Ark. — refuses to grapple with its glaring contradictions. Mostly, though, it’s because of the inordinate amount of screen time surrendered to a tiresome Passion play extravaganza. Watching people watch a stage is just lazy filmmaking, no matter how many donkeys, doves and bleating goats enliven the spectacle.

headline: ‘Berlin, I Love You’ Review: Many Stories, Not Much Feeling
abstract: The once-divided nature of Berlin isn’t given much consideration in this film, part of the Cities of Love series.
lead_paragraph: The once-divided nature of Berlin isn’t given much consideration in “Berlin, I Love You,” the fifth film in the Cities of Love anthology series. The city itself doesn’t get a whole lot of consideration, either.

headline: ‘Untogether’ Review: Adrift in Los Angeles, Looking for Love
abstract: Jemima Kirke and Lola Kirke play damaged siblings in this exasperatingly affected romantic drama from Emma Forrest.
lead_paragraph: As far as I can see, the main purpose of “Untogether” is to fetishize Jemima Kirke. Playing Andrea, a writer and barely clean heroin addict, Kirke is a Marilyn Monroe fantasy in vintage frocks and strawberry curls. Stripping, stretching, dancing and posing, she works the camera so assiduously that her latest sexual partner, Nick (Jamie Dornan), barely gets a look in.

headline: ‘Under the Eiffel Tower’ Review: In Whine, Truth
abstract: Full of midlife-crisis clichés, the film is yet another ode to the restorative magic of wine country sunshine.
lead_paragraph: In “Under the Eiffel Tower,” Stuart (Matt Walsh), an American bourbon expert fired for a “lack of passion,” likens his existence to the lives of quiet desperation described by Thoreau. “Desperation” seems too mild. When a friend (David Wain) invites Stuart to come along with him, his wife (Michaela Watkins) and their daughter (Dylan Gelula) on a French vacation, the trip has barely started before Stuart proposes marriage to the daughter — who is maybe half his age — at the base of the Eiffel Tower. And that’s before the title card.

headline: ‘One Million American Dreams’ Review: Stories From New York’s Potter’s Field
abstract: This haunting documentary guides viewers through heartbreaking tales of the lost souls buried on Hart Island.
lead_paragraph: Hart Island is in the Pelham Islands group, officially a part of the Bronx. East of the lively City Island, it is a grave site, New York City’s own potter’s field — a term from the New Testament that has come to denote a burial place for the poor, the anonymous, people without family or without family that can afford a marked resting place. The site is managed by the city’s Department of Correction and is not open to the public.

headline: Twitter Continues Its Profit Streak, While Still Shedding Users
abstract: Net income was $255 million in the fourth quarter, the fifth straight with a profit. But the company reported a loss of users for the third consecutive quarter, to 321 million.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter continues to stabilize as a business.

headline: ‘The Man Who Killed Hitler and Then the Bigfoot’ Review: Nuff Said
abstract: The movie’s plot is as absurdly sensational as its title: The government taps Sam Elliott, an aging Nazi hunter, to kill a yeti.
lead_paragraph: “The Man Who Killed Hitler and Then the Bigfoot” revives an exploitation film tradition, in which a sensational title hooks viewers for a movie that’s all windup and no pitch. The writer and director, Robert D. Krzykowski, even appears to have leaned into the concept, turning false advertising into a motif. The man (Sam Elliott), hunting for the Bigfoot, drawls that his average-footed prey is “not really living up to its name.”

headline: The Fight for Gender Equality in One of the Most Dangerous Sports on Earth
abstract: These women want the right to compete in big-wave contests — and get paid as much as men do.
lead_paragraph: These women want the right to compete in big-wave contests — and get paid as much as men do.

headline: When the Windshield Helps Drive the Car, a Repair Isn’t So Simple
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Glass', 'Computer Vision', 'Sensors', 'Cameras', 'Radar']
abstract: As vehicles rely more and more on sensors that are integrated with other parts, tuning them properly can be a life-or-death matter.
lead_paragraph: Fixing a cracked windshield used to be the kind of repair a technician could perform in a few minutes in your office parking lot while you were at work. Today, the same repair could take hours and require expensive computerized equipment in a special facility. And it will probably cost much more. If the repair is not done properly, it could have dire consequences.

headline: A Lady’s Many Scents
abstract: Pineapple juice, apple cider vinegar, douching: Is your body’s natural odor a “fixable” problem?
lead_paragraph: I’ve heard you should bathe in a “cap full” of apple cider vinegar as an alternative for douching, which also improves vaginal smell. Is there any scientific evidence to support this? — asked by Just looking for the science

headline: Onstage in France: Spanish Takes on Sex, Violence and Social Change
abstract: The annual Reims Scènes d’Europe festival showcases contemporary creation from around Europe. This year, it is focused on emerging artists from Spain.
lead_paragraph: REIMS, France — Many European theatergoers associate this French city with the working-class alienation and growing nationalism depicted in Thomas Ostermeier’s production of “Returning to Reims,” which became an international hit after its Berlin premiere in 2017. Yet a young festival in Reims is working to paint a different picture, by welcoming productions from around the Continent.

headline: Gucci and Adidas Apologize and Drop Products Called Racist
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Sneakers', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Apologies']
abstract: Gucci removed a sweater that critics said evoked blackface imagery, while Adidas abandoned a white shoe it was marketing as part of a Black History Month tribute.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week into Black History Month, in two episodes of retail déjà vu, Adidas and Gucci have apologized and pulled products criticized as racist.

headline: Measles Outbreak in Philippines Spreads Beyond Capital
keywords: ['Measles', 'Epidemics', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Politics and Government', 'Children and Childhood', 'Dengue Fever', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Health officials said a vaccine scare in 2017 had deterred parents from immunizing their children against the disease.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippines expanded the area of a declared measles outbreak on Thursday from the highly populated capital to nearby regions, after a steady rise in infections and deaths attributed to the disease in recent weeks.

headline: The Financial Crisis Put a Chill on Big Bank Deals. That Ended Thursday.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: If approved, the merger of BB&T and SunTrust would create the sixth-biggest bank in the U.S., large enough to compete against the country’s largest lenders.
lead_paragraph: Two banks announced the industry’s biggest merger in a decade on Thursday, signaling bank executives’ growing confidence that the regulatory constraints imposed after the 2008 financial crisis have begun to loosen.

headline: France Recalls Ambassador to Italy, Revealing Strains at Europe’s Core
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Yellow Vests Movement', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Building tensions reached a breaking point after Italy’s deputy prime minister, Luigi Di Maio, met this week in France with a Yellow Vest leader.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has happened rarely between European Union allies, and not between France and Italy since World War II. But on Thursday, after months of barbed commentary from Italian leaders, the French government said it had had enough: It recalled its ambassador from Rome.

headline: Review: ‘PEN15’ Goes Crudely, Sweetly Back to School
abstract: The weird kid sister of “Broad City” and “Eighth Grade,” this Hulu comedy remembers middle school painfully well.
lead_paragraph: It may be that those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. But as Maya Erskine and Anna Konkle demonstrate in the new Hulu comedy “PEN15,” the same is true of those who remember it painfully well.

headline: A ‘Dreamer’ Goes to Washington
abstract: Thursday: We talked to an undocumented Cal State Fullerton student about her trip to the State of the Union.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: January’s Most Popular Properties
abstract: The most-viewed listings of the month included a private island in the Bahamas and homes on the Upper East Side and in Hoboken, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The five most-viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in January included a private island in the Bahamas and homes on the Upper East Side and in Hoboken, N.J.

headline: The Abortion Debate
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Women and Girls']

headline: Qantas Cancels Order for the Threatened Airbus A380
abstract: The airline said the jets, made by Airbus, had not been part of its plans for some time.
lead_paragraph: The Australian carrier Qantas has canceled an outstanding 2006 order for eight Airbus A380 airplanes, adding to the uncertainty about the fate of the world’s largest passenger aircraft.

headline: E.U. Rebuffs May’s New Brexit Demand, but Promises More Talks
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations']
abstract: The British prime minister came to Brussels seeking changes to backstop arrangements for the Irish border, despite being told that none would be allowed.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain had what was described as a “robust but constructive” talk with the president of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, as her visit to Brussels on Thursday got off to a polite but cool beginning.

headline: A Costume Designer With Low Budgets and High Style
abstract: Whether he’s capturing David Lee Roth or Bed-Stuy street style, Montana Levi Blanco’s secret: an anthropological attention to detail and “amazing aggressive shopping.”
lead_paragraph: At Earrings Plaza, a Herald Square emporium devoted to all things bright, beautiful and cubic zirconium, the costume designer Montana Levi Blanco plucked a pair of feathery blue danglers from the hook. “Something with a tassel might be fun,” he said.

headline: Gift Cards Are the New Sympathy Cards
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Delivery Services', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Credits for Seamless, Uber Eats and the like are a very 21st-century way to support a grieving friend.
lead_paragraph: When my mother died suddenly last year, at the age of 63, they started coming: gift cards for Seamless, GrubHub and Uber Eats that pinged softly in my inbox. “Don’t forget to eat,” read the note accompanying one credit. Another said, “Because you can’t eat flowers.”

headline: ‘Boomerang’ Returns, as a BET Comedy
abstract: Parts of the beloved Eddie Murphy movie feel retrograde today. For the TV sequel, Lena Waithe sought to revisit the characters through a “realistic lens.”
lead_paragraph: When “Boomerang” came out in 1992 it was both an anomaly and a bit of a relief.

headline: Virginia Political Crisis Grows for Democrats and Republicans
abstract: Allegations of racism that have besieged Democrats have spread to a G.O.P. lawmaker, who helped oversee a college yearbook with racist photographs and slurs.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The political tumult in Virginia widened Thursday as the State Senate’s top Republican faced an onslaught of questions about racist photographs and slurs in a college yearbook that he helped oversee, transforming the Capitol’s nearly week-old crisis into a bipartisan reckoning over personal conduct.

headline: George Orwell Gets an Apology for a Rejection Letter (but Not for His Marmalade Recipe)
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A British cultural exchange body said it had been wrong to turn down the writer’s effort 73 years ago but stood by the criticism of his marmalade: “Bad recipe!”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rejection is a rite of passage that every writer, even some of the greatest — like George Orwell — has experienced.

headline: They Really Don’t Make Music Like They Used To
abstract: If the Eagles or Marvin Gaye fan in your life is complaining about this year’s Grammy songs, this might be why.
lead_paragraph: It’s Grammy time, and as always, watching the awards ceremony on Sunday will include a subtext of cross-generational carping: “They don’t make music the way they used to,” the boomers and Gen Xers will mutter. And they’ll be right. Music today, at least most of it, is fundamentally different from what it was in the days of yore — the 1970s and 80s.

headline: U.K. Doctors Call for Caution in Children’s Use of Screens and Social Media
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Media', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Britain’s chief medical officers declined to recommend specific age or time limits, but saw associations between social media use and mental health problems.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With even Silicon Valley worrying about the effect of technology exposure on young people, Britain’s top doctors on Thursday issued advice to families about social media and screen use. Their prescriptions: Leave phones outside the bedroom. Screen-free meals are a good idea. When in doubt, don’t upload. And get more exercise.

headline: The Bad News About Helicopter Parenting: It Works
abstract: New research shows that hyper-involved parenting is the route to kids’ success in today’s unequal world.
lead_paragraph: [The topics parents are talking about. Evidence-based guidance. Personal stories that matter. Sign up now to get NYT Parenting in your inbox every week.]

headline: Liberal Democrats Formally Call for a ‘Green New Deal,’ Giving Substance to a Rallying Cry
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: House Democrats introduced a resolution calling for a sweeping environmental and economic mobilization that would make the United States carbon neutral by 2030.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Liberal Democrats put flesh on their “Green New Deal” slogan on Thursday with a sweeping resolution intended to redefine the national debate on climate change by calling for the United States to eliminate additional emissions of carbon by 2030.

headline: John Mason, Who Expanded Ceramics’ Boundaries, Dies at 91
abstract: His large wall reliefs and other sculptures explored the artistic possibilities of clay.
lead_paragraph: John Mason, an artist who helped expand the boundaries of what could be done in ceramics by creating imposing wall reliefs and other expressionistic sculptures in a field that had often been defined by pots and vases, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Joy
abstract: We KonMari Wesley’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by Netflix’s “Tidying Up With Marie Kondo,” we decide to KonMari Wesley’s Brooklyn apartment. We ask ourselves what sparks joy in our lives and examine whether Marie Kondo’s philosophy extends into the metaphysical realm.

headline: Mixing Art, Activism and Science. And Some Tropical Fish.
abstract: The Danish collective Superflex has been seeking artful ways of tackling complex problems for 25 years. Their latest work imagines an underwater future.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Somewhere in the desert outside Palm Springs, Calif. a new drive-in movie theater is opening. It’s a simple structure, not much more than a screen mounted on a few bubblegum-color pillars, with no concession stand and very limited programming. In fact, the cinema shows only one film, and that film is about fish.

headline: Living Alone Can Be Deadly
abstract: Men who lived alone had a 23 percent increased risk for dying prematurely from any cause and a 36 percent increased risk for cardiovascular death.
lead_paragraph: Living alone may be bad for your health.

headline: Jenny Holzer’s Desert X Installation Postponed Over Concern for Bighorn Sheep
abstract: The artist’s light projection piece, which focused on gun violence, was slated to appear during the desert exhibition’s opening weekend.
lead_paragraph: People traveling to the Coachella Valley in California this weekend for the opening of Desert X, a free, public art exhibition that brings large-scale installations to the desert, won’t be seeing a new work from the artist Jenny Holzer, at least not as it was originally conceived. Ms. Holzer’s work, “BEFORE I BECAME AFRAID, 2019,” a text-based projection piece about gun violence, has been postponed indefinitely.

headline: ‘The Prodigy’ Review: Evil Genius, Average Horror
abstract: Taylor Schilling is perfect as the distraught mother of a disturbed boy in this thinly plotted horror movie.
lead_paragraph: In “The Prodigy,” a ho-hum horror movie given a mild boost by its credible performances, a small boy named Miles (Jackson Robert Scott) begins to exhibit disturbingly supernormal intelligence. Further red flags include sleep-chatting in Hungarian, abusing his babysitter and battering a classmate with a wrench. If this isn’t evidence enough of Miles’ bad-seed credentials, he also has one brown eye and one blue — weird eyes being a dead giveaway in the evil-spawn genre.

headline: ‘High Flying Bird’ Review: A Thrilling Dunk on Capitalism
abstract: The director Steven Soderbergh teams up with Tarell Alvin McCraney and André Holland to take on the contradictions of modern sports culture.
lead_paragraph: On a basketball court, “give me the rock” means “pass the ball.” In “High Flying Bird,” an exhilarating and argumentative caper concerning a sports agent, his N.B.A.-rookie client and other interested parties, the phrase takes on a slightly different connotation — something akin to “the workers should seize control of the means of production.”

headline: A.S.M.R. Videos Give People the Tingles (No, Not That Way)
keywords: ['Brain', 'Women and Girls', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Sex']
abstract: In the popular videos, the artists — mostly women — whisper, use props and role-play to help viewers feel calm. It’s not about sex, research suggests.
lead_paragraph: It tingles. It feels good. And it has nothing to do with sex.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Gov. Ralph Northam, Boredom and the Polar Vortex
abstract: The best recent teenage comments in response to our writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Students around the country have had much to say in response to our recent writing prompts about politics, podcasts, family history, digital privacy and more. Below, we’ve rounded up our favorite comments on the three most popular prompts.

headline: Behind the Cover: The Women of Big-Wave Surfing
abstract: For this issue, a look at the one of the most dangerous, rapturous sports on Earth.

keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Freedom of Religion']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump accused Democrats on Thursday morning of “presidential harassment” over congressional investigations into his finances, and he mocked Virginia politicians whose jobs are in peril after revelations they appeared in blackface.

headline: Austria Is Ordered to Pay $1.7 Million for House Where Hitler Was Born
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Neo Nazi Groups']
abstract: The government sought for decades to take over the property in Braunau, to ensure that it did not fall into the hands of someone seeking to glorify its dark history. But it didn’t pay enough for the property, a court has found.
lead_paragraph: A decades-long dispute involving the house where Hitler was born took a new turn on Thursday, as a court in Austria ordered the country’s government to pay the former owner of the building the equivalent of $1.7 million.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: January 2019
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first 2019 edition of Teenagers in The Times. This roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com appears on the first Thursday of each month during the school year.

headline: The Patient Had Bone Cancer. The Diagnosis Arrived 240 Million Years Too Late.
abstract: The fossil of an ancient animal teaches a sad lesson: Cancer has been around for a very, very long time.
lead_paragraph: Certainly the patient never knew where the hip pain came from, or why its left leg stopped working. The diagnosis arrived only 240 million years later, when a femur turned up in an ancient lake bed in Germany, one side marred by a malignant bone tumor.

headline: Alicja Kwade Selected for the Met’s Roof Garden Installation
abstract: Her installation, “ParaPivot,” dominated by two large metal frames, will be on view from April 16 through Oct. 27
lead_paragraph: The Met’s Roof Garden Commission is a rite of summer for New Yorkers and a world stage for artists lucky enough to be chosen. This year’s fortunate selection is the Berlin-based artist Alicja Kwade, who will be presenting two abstract sculptures dominated by large metal frames that she described as “a kind of planetary system.”

headline: The Biden Fallacy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Tax', 'Income Inequality', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Struggle against the powerful, not accommodation of their interests, is how America produced the conditions for its greatest social reforms.
lead_paragraph: There’s something odd about the self-described moderates and centrists considering a run for president. If “moderation” or “centrism” means holding broadly popular positions otherwise marginalized by extremists in either party, then these prospective candidates don’t quite fit the bill.

headline: Make T Something | Faye Toogood
abstract: The British designer creates a wearable manifesto using only a few select items, one wild-card object and a copy of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The British designer creates a wearable manifesto using only a few select items, one wild-card object and a copy of The New York Times.

headline: Carlos Ghosn May Have Spent Company Funds on Wedding Party, Renault Says
abstract: In an acknowledgment of possible wrongdoing by its former leader, the French carmaker suggested he might have misused company funds for a lavish event at Versailles.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French carmaker Renault on Thursday suggested publicly for the first time that Carlos Ghosn, its embattled former chairman and chief executive, may have misused company money to finance a lavish Marie Antoinette-themed party at Versailles to celebrate his second marriage and his new wife’s 50th birthday.

headline: How to Fashion a Jacket Out of The New York Times
abstract: The designer Faye Toogood — featured in our latest issue — takes the “Make T Something” challenge.
lead_paragraph: For T’s Spring Women’s Fashion issue, on newsstands Feb. 17, the designer Faye Toogood invited us into her studio, a “vertiginously thin, four-story, 1,800-square-foot Victorian townhouse” in London that was once “a downtrodden squat,” writes Nancy Hass. We returned the invitation and asked Toogood to swing by our video studio, to film an episode of “Make T Something.” See what she created in under an hour using only the supplies we had on hand, plus a wild-card item of her choosing.

headline: A Work Space Fit for an Ever-Changing Designer
abstract: In a Victorian townhouse in East London, Faye Toogood has built a studio that honors both her distinct eye and the certainty of impermanence.
lead_paragraph: UNCOMPLICATED BEAUTY HAS never interested the designer Faye Toogood. She doesn’t care about what’s in fashion; in fact, she would prefer her work make you uneasy, suddenly unsure of what year it is, even what century. Such disorientation is embedded, like an alien fossil, in the oeuvre of the polymathic Toogood, 42, who has for the last decade created objects, furniture, clothing and residential interiors that seem simultaneously futuristic and prehistoric: chairs with backs like the handle of a garden spade; sparsely furnished Georgian homes with murky gray walls and metal cage bookshelves; oversize, genderless garments of boiled wool and ivory canvas. She is widely considered to be the most poetic of contemporary design’s minimalists.

headline: A Divided Senate Committee Advances William Barr Nomination
abstract: The acting attorney general, Matthew G. Whitaker, said on Thursday that he will not appear before Congress on Friday unless the committee assures him he will not be subpoenaed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A polarized Senate Judiciary Committee advanced the nomination of William P. Barr to be President Trump’s second confirmed attorney general on Thursday, as Republicans and Democrats split over his views on executive authority and the special counsel’s ongoing Russia investigation.

headline: ‘To Dust’ Review: Death, Decay and Grief Wrapped in a Buddy Movie
abstract: Geza Rohrig and Matthew Broderick play an odd couple in search of scientific answers. They find much more than that.
lead_paragraph: “To Dust” runs an hour and a half, and that feels right for a buddy movie whose comedy is as stubborn as this one’s. But the movie is also trying — daring — to seriously consider grief, and that movie could have gone on for much longer. You can feel the script, by Jason Begue and Shawn Snyder, straining to tickle an audience. So it has a bereft widowed Hasidic cantor named Shmuel (Geza Rohrig) team up with Albert, a dumpy, mildly grizzled community college biology professor — and complete stranger — played by Matthew Broderick.

headline: Horse Races in Britain Called Off Until Next Week After Flu Outbreak
abstract: British horse racing authorities identified three horses infected with equine influenza and called for a suspension of races until others could be tested.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain has canceled horse races at least until the middle of next week after three horses tested positive for equine influenza.

headline: Frida Kahlo’s Home Is Still Unlocking Secrets, 50 Years Later
abstract: The artist’s life, through clothing, jewelry, objects, films.
lead_paragraph: Hard to imagine she once worked in shadow; when she had her first New York exhibition, in 1938, Vogue preferred to name her “Madame Diego Rivera.” For there may be no artist today as famous as Frida Kahlo, now recognizable from Oaxaca to Ouagadougou — with those big brown eyes framed by her notched unibrow, those pursed lips topped by a whisper of a mustache. Certainly no woman in art history commands her popular acclaim.

abstract: For a third day, subway riders are reporting a strong odor of gas at stations in Brooklyn. Riders and M.T.A. workers have said it is making them sick.

headline: After Heated Exchange, Matthew Whitaker Says He Will Testify Friday Before the House
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Subpoenas', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Democrats want to ask the acting attorney general about the Russia investigation and whether President Trump fired Jeff Sessions to undermine it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a heated back-and-forth, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Jerrold Nadler, bowed to the wishes of the acting attorney general, Matthew G. Whitaker, that he not issue a subpoena while Mr. Whitaker testifies before the committee as scheduled on Friday.

headline: Racing Through the Polar Vortex
abstract: And you thought it was chilly in your living room? These athletes competed in an ultramarathon in Minnesota during last week’s misery.
lead_paragraph: Remember the polar vortex and those subzero temperatures that plagued vast swaths of the United States last week? While much of the country was hibernating with hot cocoa, 146 athletes were competing in a 135-mile race in northern Minnesota.

headline: Can the Grammys Please Anyone?
keywords: ['Grammy Awards', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The awards show made a series of changes in the past year to address its lack of diversity. But whether new nominees will win — or big names will show up — isn’t guaranteed.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards are supposed to be music’s biggest party. But in recent years the show has also become a piñata for critics, activists and even major artists over a host of issues like race and gender — and, oh yes, music.

headline: Jack White Wins Eurovision. Kind Of.
abstract: The former White Stripes frontman was added to the credits for the 2018 Eurovision winner, “Toy,” a pop anthem sung by Netta Barzilai of Israel.

headline: Sandy Hook Families Gain in Defamation Suits Against Alex Jones
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: As the cases inch toward trial, the conspiracy theorist faces the possibility that he will have to be deposed and provide business records.
lead_paragraph: Families of the Sandy Hook school shooting victims have won a series of victories in their defamation suits against the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones that would open Mr. Jones’s business records to them and compel him to speak under oath.

headline: The Artist Creating a 150-Foot-Long Glass Rainbow
abstract: This summer, Sarah Cain will bring a high-art tradition into an unexpected setting: the San Francisco International Airport.
lead_paragraph: The first paintings that Sarah Cain remembers admiring as a teenager were works by Joan Mitchell, Philip Guston and Robert Motherwell which, thanks to a public arts fund, lined the walls of an otherwise dismal underground mall in Albany, N.Y., not far from where she grew up, in Kinderhook. “My parents didn’t really take me to museums, so that is where I saw the first real art, mixed in with shops and a McDonald’s,” says Cain, who is now 40 and an established artist herself. In July, she will unveil a major public work of her own, a 150-foot-long series of 37 vividly colorful stained-glass windows, funded by the San Francisco Arts Commission, which she hopes will inspire passers-by in an equally unlikely setting: the new AirTrain terminal at the city’s international airport.

abstract: This 1950 musical has some charming numbers, but without a monster personality at its center it seems like less of a comedy than a requiem.

But in his Op-Ed “A Better Way to Tax the Rich,” Steven Rattner, a contributing opinion writer and Wall Street executive, says there are “more sensible” ways for the wealthy to contribute, “in particular, by increasing the tax rate on capital gains and dividends and closing loopholes.”

headline: Why Girls Beat Boys at School and Lose to Them at the Office
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Education (K-12)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Hard work and discipline help girls outperform boys in class, but that advantage disappears in the work force. Is school the problem?
lead_paragraph: From elementary school through college, girls are more disciplined about their schoolwork than boys; they study harder and get better grades. Girls consistently outperform boys academically. And yet, men nonetheless hold a staggering 95 percent  of the top positions in the largest public companies.

headline: Valeria Luiselli, at Home in Two Worlds
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: The Mexican writer has made a name for herself with experimental books and essays. Her latest, “Lost Children Archive,” is a road trip novel that shows off her intellectual sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Christmas, a group of 20 or so people crowded into the Mexican novelist Valeria Luiselli’s living room. Luiselli dipped in and out among her guests, serving mulled wine as school-aged children from Still Waters in a Storm, an educational center in Brooklyn focused on reading and writing, prepared to perform an original musical adapted from Cervantes’ “Don Quixote.” The children had worked with the center’s founder, Stephen Haff, to translate the book from the Spanish and write songs reinterpreting the story with a chorus of migrant children. By the time Haff told the children to find their spots on the small makeshift stage, the seats had filled up, so Luiselli sat on the floor next to her 9-year-old daughter, Maia. It wasn’t the first time Luiselli had seen the show, but she still cried, as did her daughter, when the children sang songs with lyrics like, “Innocence needs a home.”

headline: Nets’ Caris LeVert Set to Return 3 Months After Scary Foot Injury

headline: Why the Weinstein Company Bankruptcy Hurt Native Women
abstract: An agreement to donate all profits from “Wind River” would have helped a group for Indigenous women. But the company that bought out Weinstein probably won’t recognize the pact.
lead_paragraph: As dozens of women stepped forward in fall 2017 with accusations that Harvey Weinstein had sexually assaulted them, the writer and director Taylor Sheridan made several demands of Weinstein’s doomed company: No longer distribute his latest feature, “Wind River,” starring Jeremy Renner and Elizabeth Olsen, about a murdered Indigenous woman on a reservation in Wyoming, and also strip all traces of the company’s name from the film. And donate future profits from the film to the National Indigenous Women’s Resource Center.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Is news fake? Is news dying? The journalism business and the ways people consume its wares have come in for a lot of scrutiny lately — healthy scrutiny, on the whole, even if reporters and editors are collectively and understandably anxious about the state of their industry these days. (The state of our industry, I should say: I am not exempt.) If you’re anxious, too, or even if you’re just interested in what it all means for you as a reader and a curious citizen of the world, we have some books to help you navigate it all. On newspapers: “Merchants of Truth,” by the former New York Times editor Jill Abramson, and “Breaking News,” by the former Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger. On social media: “Zucked,” by the venture capitalist and early Facebook fan Roger McNamee. He’s not a fan anymore, as you’ll see from his subtitle: “Waking Up to the Facebook Catastrophe.”

headline: 7 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend

headline: I Can Control the Symptoms of My Autism. But Why Should I?
abstract: Our advice columnist answers a letter from a teenager wrestling with what is socially appropriate.
lead_paragraph: I was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome when I was 8. Now I’m a teenager, and that isn’t a diagnosis anymore. I have autism spectrum disorder now. I’m considered “high functioning.” But when I’m happy or upset, I sometimes rock my body or flap my hands. My mom says I shouldn’t do this in public because it’s socially inappropriate and may be distracting to others. But I think it’s O.K. I’m not hurting anyone. And even though I can control the rocking and flapping now, I don’t think I should have to. What do you think?

headline: Playing to Win: Using Sports to Develop Evidence-Based Arguments
abstract: From honing arguments on current sports controversies to making a case for the G.O.A.T. to proposing needed rules changes, here are some ideas for using sports to sharpen student skills.
lead_paragraph: Sports is not just about X’s and O’s or wins and losses; it’s also about ethics and economics, race and gender, science and technology, joy and camaraderie, and nearly everything in between. Sports allows us to admire the awesomeness of the human body and the artistry of athletes in action, and to explore stories of grit and resilience and our need for heroes and villains.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ Season 2, Episode 4: On Death Watch
abstract: In this week’s episode, Saru faces an almost certain death, and the writers end up cheating the audience.
lead_paragraph: The most famous death scene in “Star Trek” history — one that transcended the franchise — was undoubtedly Spock’s demise at the end of the 1982 film “Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.” It was momentous for multiple reasons: First, the death forced Kirk to actually confront the no-win scenario. Second — and perhaps most important — they actually killed off Spock. They offed a beloved character, shocking audiences and making the final scene (“I have been — and always shall be — your friend”) all the more meaningful.

headline: Poem: How’d Your Parents Die Again?
abstract: Neither human sympathy nor nature’s bounty can fill the void left by her parents’ early deaths.
lead_paragraph: The basic rules for writing a ghazal seem straightforward — five to 15 couplets, one word repeated at the end of each stanza — but transporting this seventh-century Arabian form into a 21st-century American lyric is no mean trick. Fatimah Asghar’s brilliant offering is a dexterous blend of Old World endurance and New World bravado. Neither human sympathy nor nature’s bounty can fill the void left by her parents’ early deaths; the ferocious melancholy of that single-word refrain circles their absence as if to say: There is no escaping a loss this large — only endurance. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: Against Romance: An Un-Valentine
abstract: We’re supposed to subject our relationships to some recipe for permanent swoon and are made to believe we are failing if we just live in reality.
lead_paragraph: One Valentine’s Day many years ago, my spouse, Gil, brought home a bouquet of roses. I am Dutch and he is Israeli, so neither of us had grown up celebrating Valentine’s Day. But it was our first year as graduate students in the United States, and one of his classmates, shocked that he was planning to spend the evening at the library, convinced him that he’d risk losing my love if he didn’t bring me a romantic gift.

headline: All the Ways We’ll Beat the Winter Blues This Season
keywords: ['Winter (Season)', 'Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Novelty tips for people with moods.
lead_paragraph: It appears once again that February has arrived, as it manages to every year, though it wasn’t exactly invited. The world is dark and postures are slumped as people trudge around in floor-length puffer coats, hunching inward for warmth like a dreary colony of sun-starved caterpillars. In New York City, a strained quiet has settled in, punctuated only by the hiss of a thousand radiators.

headline: Picture Books That Bring Black Heroes to Life
abstract: The life of a legendary cowboy, a tribute to the poet Gwendolyn Brooks, a shout-out to hip-hop and more.
lead_paragraph: African-American picture books have always been successful at capturing the breadth, depth and beauty of the black experience, allowing children to gain much-needed access to the strong legacy and vibrant history of African-American art and storytelling. But how we present this story is always undergoing revision and refinement, as four new books — from a closer view of plantation life to a visually rich depiction of the history of hip-hop — show. In these books, word and art combine to give us fresh insight into the lives, creativity and achievements of a truly resilient and profound people.

headline: Mountains Aren’t Just for Skiing
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Winter (Season)', 'Snowshoes']
abstract: An increasing number of people are taking up snow hiking: wintertime trekking using snowshoes or special boots. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Snow hiking is growing in popularity as a wintertime sport globally. Alta Badia ski resort, in Italy’s Dolomites region, saw 50,000 snow hikers in the winter of 2017- 18, compared with 30,000 the previous winter, according to the local tourist board. Companies that offer snow hiking excursions also report a rise in business: Discover Banff Tours, which runs snow hiking trips in Banff National Park, had more than 10,000 participants last winter, compared with 6,000 in the winter of 2015-16, said its founder, Jonathan Welsh.

headline: Oscar Rewind: The Acceptance Speech That Spawned Another Movie

headline: 20 Wines Under $20: A Little More Money for a Lot More Wine
abstract: Value in wine does not mean the cheapest price. The extra dimensions of distinctiveness and interest usually require $15 to $20 a bottle.

For just as long, I have heard the persistent objection that $15 to $20 is too much to spend for a bottle of wine, and the suggestion that I instead focus on wines that are $8 to $10.

headline: Australia’s Most Important Writer Isn’t Allowed Into the Country
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Writing and Writers', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Behrouz Boochani won the country’s most valuable literary prize for a book he wrote via WhatsApp. Will it do anything to change refugee policy?
lead_paragraph: Many writers have earned prison time as well as prizes; the Nobel laureates Liu Xiaobo and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn come immediately to mind. But there seems to be no precedent for what happened in Australia last week, when an author named Behrouz Boochani won the country’s most valuable literary prize, the Victorian Prize for Literature, but was unable to collect his stipend in person. The same nation praising him is also keeping him in indefinite detention on a small island in the Pacific.

abstract: A movement that can detect a racist dog-whistle from miles away is strangely deaf when it comes to some of the barking on its own side of the fence.
lead_paragraph: It happened again last month in Detroit. Pro-Palestinian demonstrators seized the stage of the National L.G.B.T.Q. Task Force’s marquee conference, “Creating Change” and demanded a boycott of Israel. “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free,” they chanted — the tediously malign, thinly veiled call to end Israel as a Jewish state.

headline: Serial Killer Bruce McArthur Gets Life Sentence in Case That Terrorized Gay Men
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Serial Murders', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The murders prompted concerns that Toronto police had not taken gay residents’ fears seriously.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Bruce McArthur, who pleaded guilty to eight murders that brought fear to Toronto’s gay community, was sentenced Friday to life with no chance of parole for 25 years.

headline: Virginia Is in Turmoil. Here’s a Breakdown of 11 Days of Scandal.
abstract: Last week, a racist photo from the yearbook of Gov. Ralph Northam surfaced online. Since then, it’s been chaos for the state’s top Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Updated Feb. 11

headline: Islands Helped Penguins Evolve. Then Hungry Humans Showed Up.
keywords: ['Penguins', 'your-feed-science', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The discovery of two extinct penguin subspecies in New Zealand is a cautionary tale of the threats faced by the waddling birds in the wild.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of years, penguins have darted through the waters of the southern oceans, chasing fish and surfacing to nest on islands and landmasses sprinkled from the Galápagos to the Antarctic. Today there are around 20 penguin species, ranging from the playful Adelie to the stately Emperor. But there once were other penguins, including a previously unknown subspecies of dwarf yellow-eyed penguin in New Zealand.

headline: Just a Little Fancy
abstract: Make a scallop pasta for Valentine’s Day, and crunchy chicken for real life.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Next Thursday, as you may or may not know, is Valentine’s Day. I am probably the only member of the Food department who goes out to dinner on Valentine’s Day. I know. I get it. But really, is it a treat for me if I have to cook after work? That doesn’t sound like a treat for me? And if my husband cooks, then I do the dishes — also not a treat for me? So we go out! Someone makes us manhattans, and then we eat steak. It’s corny, and I love it.

headline: When Private Fights Over Millions Become Public (Things Get Ugly)
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Wills and Estates', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Legal action among wealthy family members has created a booming business for lawyers who specialize in estate litigation. But financial advisers say there are ways to minimize conflict.
lead_paragraph: There are private family squabbles, and then there are family squabbles that splash into public view, shining a spotlight on a bitter dispute.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Knife-Wielding Man in New York City
abstract: Two officers were escorting a man from an apartment on the Lower East Side when he grabbed a knife and attacked his partner, officials said.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Barbra Siperstein, Crusader for Transgender Rights, Dies at 76
abstract: Married with three children, she became a vigorous advocate after her wife died. Her name is on a new New Jersey law on gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Barbra Siperstein, a crusader for transgender rights, died on Sunday, two days after a law bearing her name went into effect granting New Jerseyans the right to amend the gender on their birth certificates without proof of surgery. She was 76.

headline: Is Everyone in Washington Writing a Political Tell-All?
abstract: Two more books by former members of President Trump’s administration hit the best-seller list this week.
lead_paragraph: Is everyone in Washington writing a tell-all? It sure seems like it. Though it’s not surprising to see so many books about President Trump on the best-seller list, it is surprising that, barely two years into his term, so many of them are written by people who were once key players in his administration. Some are effusive: In “The Briefing,” Trump’s perpetually beleaguered former press secretary, Sean Spicer, called his boss “a unicorn riding a unicorn over a rainbow,” and Anthony Scaramucci, who was briefly the White House communications director, wrote in “Trump: The Blue Collar President” that for a “guy working in finance, who wanted to rise through the economic classes and reach for the Gold Ring, Mr. Trump was the Great Gatsby.”

headline: The Playlist: Ariana Grande’s Next Step, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Kim Petras, Khalid, the Japanese House, Quando Rondo and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Review: An American Gothic Opera Speaks Softly and Hypnotically
abstract: Robert Ashley’s “Improvement (Don Leaves Linda),” through Feb. 16, is a story about marital separation and an allegory of the Jewish diaspora.
lead_paragraph: Robert Ashley’s “Improvement (Don Leaves Linda)” isn’t the first opera to have its heroine pathetically forsaken in an American desert. Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” starts its final act in one, with the title character “alone, lost, abandoned,” as she cries in a majestic outpouring of an aria.

headline: Can We Love Ourselves the Way We Love Our Children?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A kindergarten application essay as a mother’s prompt for self-evaluation.
lead_paragraph: This is the week we learn where my 4-year-old daughter will attend kindergarten next September. I devoted many hours last fall to composing an essay about her — an important essay, because it was for her applications to private schools. I spent more energy on this piece of work than I ever spent on my college or grad school applications.

headline: A Single Earring, White Boots and More Simple Outfit Upgrades
abstract: This season, brands let timeless wardrobe essentials speak for themselves.
lead_paragraph: This season, brands let timeless wardrobe essentials speak for themselves.

headline: How to Build a Minimalist Outfit That Isn’t Boring
abstract: A breakdown of simple but striking pieces, from a silk slip dress to a perfect blazer, and ideas for how to wear them.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to identify as a minimalist to appreciate a perfect white T-shirt, a streamlined slip dress or a simple, strategically cut blazer, but recently brands including Balenciaga and Givenchy have demonstrated the power of letting these wardrobe essentials speak for themselves. A pared-down look doesn’t require a monastic approach to dressing, but rather complementing clean-cut staples with a few considered touches: a simple chain necklace to accent a T-shirt, a pair of white boots to sharpen a dress, or a jacket with subtly voluminous shoulders. Here, our favorite minimalist pieces from the new resort collections — and some ideas for how to wear them.

headline: Aboriginal Hunters’ Fires Help Restore an Australian Desert
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Indigenous Australians', 'Wildfires', 'Land Use Policies', 'Deserts', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Conservation of Resources', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: A study of how the Martu shaped their land presents an example where humans seem to benefit an environment perceived as wilderness.
lead_paragraph: In Australia in recent decades, the bilby, the bettong, or rat kangaroo, the brush-tailed possum and other medium-sized mammals all disappeared from the Western Desert. It was a mystery: Typically bigger animals vanish first — often only after people show up.

headline: Virginia Lieutenant Governor Faces Eroding Support From Democrats After New Accuser Speaks
abstract: The new allegation follows one by a California professor, Vanessa Tyson, who says Mr. Fairfax sexually assaulted her in 2004.
lead_paragraph: A second woman came forward Friday with claims that she had been sexually assaulted by Lt. Gov. Justin E. Fairfax of Virginia, intensifying the weeklong political crisis in the state and leading top fellow Democrats to call for Mr. Fairfax to resign.

headline: For Women Working in Men’s Sports, It Is Not an Honor Just to Be Nominated
abstract: The slow integration of women into coaching roles in men’s leagues is not only a setback for the women, but also for the leagues, which are leaving a deep pool of talent untapped.
lead_paragraph: The hiring of the W.N.B.A. point guard Kristi Toliver as a full-time assistant coach with the N.B.A.’s Washington Wizards while she is still an active player was widely applauded as a notable new achievement for women in coaching.

headline: Sierra Leone Declares National Emergency Over Rape of Young Girls
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Politics and Government', "Women's Rights", 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: President Julius Maada Bio said a majority of the victims were under 15, and announced measures to combat sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amid growing outrage over the rape of a 5-year-old girl, the president of Sierra Leone declared sexual violence a national emergency, vowing that sex with minors would be punishable by life in prison.

headline: Ivanka Trump Denies President Was Involved in Granting Security Clearance
abstract: Asked what had delayed her and Jared Kushner’s security clearances, Ms. Trump said it was “a backlog that exists of close to a million clearances across government.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s oldest daughter, who serves as a senior adviser in the White House, denied on Friday that her father was involved in issuing security clearances for her or her husband, Jared Kushner.

lead_paragraph: Jason Wu Collection 2019 Fall RTW Collection.

headline: A Super Bowl Mermaid Ad and a Sexist Audition
abstract: A December essay for Vice was titled “My Bikini Audition From Hell Shows How Little Hollywood Has Changed.” It turns out it was about a Super Bowl ad.
lead_paragraph: In the first quarter of the Super Bowl on Sunday, in front of nearly 100 million viewers watching on CBS, Anheuser-Busch ran a commercial for its Bon & Viv hard seltzer brand. Two women, clad in cropped short-sleeved collared shirts, played the mythical mermaid founders of the brand and pitched the beverage to a group of talking sharks under the sea.

headline: Review: A Tenor Reaches 18 High C’s at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: Javier Camarena responded to an ecstatic ovation after his big aria in Donizetti’s “La Fille du Régiment” by repeating the piece and its high notes.
lead_paragraph: Javier Camarena has done it again.

headline: Virginia’s Racist History Clashes With New South Image
abstract: Revelations about past racist behavior by top Virginia politicians are testing the state’s reputation as a progressive-minded beacon that backed Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — L. Douglas Wilder, a grandson of slaves, became America’s first elected black governor 30 years ago, winning in Virginia in part by finessing the racist history of the state that is now roiling its politics once more.

headline: Norman Seabrook Was Once a Union PowerBroker in New York. Now He Is Going to Prison.
abstract: Mr. Seabrook, the former head of the correction officers’ union, was sentenced to prison for taking a bribe to steer the union’s money into a risky hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Jeff Bezos vs. The National Enquirer: How a Tabloid Tale Escalated, and Exploded
abstract: A primer on the players and plot points in a fight that erupted on Thursday in accusations of extortion.
lead_paragraph: A surprise divorce announcement by the world’s richest man, steamy texts, a private investigation, claims of blackmail — and a suspicion that politics are behind it all. These aren’t plot points in a movie coming soon to Amazon Prime. They’re the increasingly surprising events swirling around Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder.

headline: Review: Death, Two Ways, at the New York Philharmonic
abstract: Vastly unalike, Tan Dun’s “Fire Ritual” and Brahms’s “A German Requiem” are both full of luminous color and reflect complex attitudes toward death.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things that inspire music, one of the most paradoxically productive is death. Whether the sounds it brings forth are meant to console, to offer catharsis, or to build a bridge to the soul of the departed, common to all is a refusal to accept that definitive silence.

headline: Soccer Pioneers, Priced Out by Progress
abstract: Doncaster Belles used to be women’s soccer royalty, champions of England and a fixture in the F.A. Cup final. Now, as investment floods into the women’s game, a new history is being written without them.
lead_paragraph: ROSSINGTON, England — Over the years, Sheila Edmunds has done pretty much everything for the Doncaster Belles. Half a century ago, she was among the group of friends who founded the club. For 25 years, she wore the team’s No. 8 jersey and, for a while, its captain’s armband.

headline: Why a Town Is Finally Honoring a Black Veteran Attacked by Its White Police Chief
abstract: Sgt. Isaac Woodard Jr., a decorated veteran, was brutally beaten by the police in a small South Carolina town in 1946. Now the town is facing up to its past.
lead_paragraph: It was a racial assault so vicious that it became one of the early chords of the civil rights movement, and led to the desegregation of the military.

headline: Kate Spade New York: Fall 2019
abstract: Kate Spade New York 2019 Fall RTW Collection.
lead_paragraph: Kate Spade New York 2019 Fall RTW Collection.

headline: Butterflies, Bulldozers and Barbed Wire Rally Border Wall Opponents
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'States (US)']
abstract: From peaceful protests to resolutions condemning the fencing, communities along the United States-Mexico border are engaged in acts of resistance.
lead_paragraph: As a political fight rages in Washington over President Trump’s demand for $5.7 billion in border wall funding, there have been spirited acts of resistance on the United States-Mexico border.

headline: Jeff Bezos Isn’t Afraid of Total Exposure
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'ADULTERY', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Normally the web is a haven for the dark side. This time, the Amazon chief executive used it to let in the light.
lead_paragraph: I cannot quite believe I am writing about Jeff Bezos’ sex life for the second time in two weeks, let alone about his penis. But Mr. Bezos brought all of himself back into the news on Thursday by writing a blockbuster post on Medium accusing American Media, which owns The National Enquirer, of blackmail. The post is addressed to David Pecker, the head of American Media, and titled, “No Thank You, Mr. Pecker.”

headline: The New A.A.F. Is Betting on Football, and on Betting
abstract: The Alliance of American Football kicks off this weekend with plans to promote itself to content-hungry football fans and action-hungry sports bettors.
lead_paragraph: There are a multitude of ways to lose money in sports, and historically one of the most dependable ways is to start a professional football league. Charlie Ebersol knows this better than most. He had a front-row seat when his father, Dick, the longtime NBC executive, was a partner with the XFL for its only season in 2001.

headline: Jeff Bezos Said He Was a Victim of Extortion and Blackmail. What’s the Difference?
abstract: Blackmail and extortion schemes have existed for centuries, from 17th-century Scottish farmers paying off plunderers to David Letterman revealing he was targeted to keep his affairs quiet.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the world’s wealthiest person, revealed in a sensational blog post on Thursday that he believed he was the victim of “extortion and blackmail” by the company behind The National Enquirer. He accused the company, American Media Inc., of threatening to release graphic photos of him.

headline: An Enduring Legacy From an Editor’s Closet
abstract: A posthumous sale of clothes from the collection of Franca Sozzani, the influential Vogue Italia editor, benefits a genomics fund at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: “No sooner said than done,” is a poor rendering into English of the excellent Italian phrase “Detto fatto,” with its declarative immediacy and percussive consonants. Yet it’s as good a window as one is likely to get into the workings of Franca Sozzani’s mind.

headline: Milla Jovovich, Kim Kardashian and the Chainsmokers at amfAR Gala
abstract: Benefits were also held for the New York Philharmonic and the Viennese Opera Ball.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were also held for the New York Philharmonic and the Viennese Opera Ball.

headline: Where to Stream 7 of Albert Finney’s Best Films
abstract: The acclaimed British actor died Thursday, leaving behind a body of work that spanned nearly six decades.
lead_paragraph: Albert Finney, the distinguished British thespian and five-time Oscar nominee, died Thursday at 82. Although he retired from the screen several years ago (his final film appearance was in the 2012 James Bond film “Skyfall”), he left behind a rich variety of astonishing roles from a career that spanned nearly six decades: the working-class “angry young men” of British films like “Saturday Night and Sunday Morning”; the flawed middle-age men of “Under the Volcano” and “The Browning Version”; and his unforgettable roles in big-budget movie musicals like “Scrooge” and “Annie.”

abstract: The New York Philharmonic's new season and Messiaen in a crypt were among the highlights.
